9800019
*041  $arus
*24510$aLutch. Utcheno-literaturnyj sbornik.
*260  $aSt.Petersburg
$bG.E.Blagosvetlov
$c1866
*300  $a4, 536, 234 pages
*440 0$aVolume 2
*500  $aSource: National Library of Russia, St. Petersburg: Union Catalogue of illegal and forbidden printed matter 19th century, Volume I-III
*505  $aNote: A scientific and literary anthology, that G. E. 
Blagosvetlov began to publish instead of the forbidden magazine 
"Russkoye slovo". It contained articles, short stories, novels and 
poetry.
*505  $aNote: Volume I came out on March 22, 1866 and was not forbidden 
although that publication had called a special attention of the 
censors. They just didn't have a legal basis to ban it. In order to 
avoid such situations in the future, a law forbidding the 
editor-in-chief of a banned edition continue his work was passed. 
Volume II was banned on June 25, 1866.
*506  $bCensoring body: Committee of Ministers
*506  $eThe Committee of Ministers banned the book on October 15, 
1874.(The correspondence between the censoring and the legal bodies 
took several years.) 3475 copies were destroyed.
*518  $aOctober 15, 1874
*518  $3Volume II was banned on June 25, 1866
*651  $a8064
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^

9800597
*041  $alat
*10010$aOvid [Publius Ovidius Naso]
*24510$aArs Amatoria
$b(The Art of Love)
*260  $cc. 1 BC
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Emperor Augustus, Savonarolae
*506  $eDescription and result of incident: A.D. 8 Rome : The Emperor 
Augustus banished Ovid for writing "Ars Amatoria" and for an unknown 
act of folly. A.D. 8 in Rome: Ovid was sent to the Greek town of Tomi, 
near the mouth of the Danube, where he died in exile eight years later. 
1497 Florence : The Works of Ovid were cast with those of Dante and his 
friend Propertius, into the great bonfire of Savonarola, as erotic, 
impious, and tending to corrupt.
*518  $a0008 A.D., 1497
*651  $a8033
*691  $aPolitical
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800598
*041  $alat
*10010$aOvid [Publius Ovidius Naso]
*24510$aElegies
*260  $cc. 1 BC
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Poems
*506  $bCensoring body: Savonarola, Archbishop of Canterbury
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: A.D. 8 in Rome: Ovid was 
sent to the Greek town of Tomi, near the mouth of the Danube, where he 
died in exile eight years later. 1497 Florence : The Works of Ovid were 
cast with those of Dante and his friend Propertius, into the great 
bonfire of Savonarola, as erotic, impious, and tending to corrupt. 1599 
The Archbishop of Canterbury and the Bishop of London ordered the 
burning of, among other works, Christopher Marlowe's translation of 
Ovid's "Elegies" and Sir John Davies "Epigrammes," which satirizes 
contemporary authorities - apparently less because of their content 
than because of the work with which they were bound.
*518  $a1497 and 1599
*651  $a8033
*651  $a8051
*691  $aReligious
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800599
*041  $alat
*10010$aPretonius, Gaius [d.c. A.D. 66]
*24510$aSatyricon
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Comic, picaresque romance. Surviving 
portions probably represent about one tenth of the complete work
*506  $bCensoring body: City of Westminster in Londone
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1934 England-London : This 
comic satire on Roman life in the time of Nero, under whom Petronius 
served as a consul and "arbiter" of the public entertainment, survives 
as a fragment. According to one authority (Donald Thomas, "A Long Time 
Burning"), the first English translation to get in trouble was a modern 
one. The book was ordered destroyed by the police court of the City of 
Westminster.
*518  $a1934
*651  $a8051
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^
9800600
*10010$aArius [c. A.D. 256-336]
*24510$aThaleia
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: This poetic verse publicized the 
thesis which was a new approach to the New Testament. The thesis was 
widely spread by tactic of popular songs written for labourers and 
travelers.
*506  $bCensoring body: Council of Niceae
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: A.D.321 : Arius, presbyter 
of Alexandria, was excommunicated in 321 for heretical teachings about 
the nature of Christ. A.D. 325 : the Council of Nicea condemned his 
"Thaleia", the collection of popular verses expressing his ideas. 
A.D.325 : the Council of Nicea exiled him. This was the first writing 
banned by the Catholic Church.
*518  $a0321 - 0325 A.D
*651  $a8000
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800601
*10010$a[Various]
*24510$aThe Bible
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 553 Italy-Rome : Emperor 
Justinian issued a decree commanding exclusive use of the Greek and 
Latin version of the "Bible" and forbidding the "Midrash", but 
accepting the Hebrew exposition of the Old Testament.
*518  $a0553
*651  $a8033

9800602
*10010$a[Various]
*24510$aThe Bible
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Synod of Canterbury at St.Paul's, 
London
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1409 England : The Synod 
of Canterbury at St.Paul's, London, issued a decree forbidding the 
translation of the Scripture from one tongue to another, and the 
reading of a translation later than that of John Wycliffe under penalty 
of excommunication, unless special license be obtained.
*518  $a1409
*651  $a8051
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800603
*10010$a[Various]
*24510$aThe Bible
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1525-1526 : The New 
Testament, partly translated by William Tyndale, was printed at 
Cologne, as it was violently opposed by the clergy in England. 
1525-1526 : The sheets of 6,000 copies of the Testament were smuggled 
into England where they were publicly burned by the dignitaries of the 
Church, thus becoming the first printed book to be banned in England.
*518  $a1525-1526
*651  $a8051
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800604
*10010$a[Various]
*24510$aThe Bible
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1538 France-Paris : 
Regnault, famous printer of English books was seized by the Inquisition 
while printing the "great" Bible for Cromwell. 1535 : The Old and New 
Testaments translated by Miles Coverdale were the first complete Bible 
to be printed in English. Not being licensed by the Church or State, it 
had to be printed on the Continent. 1538 France-Paris : Regnault was 
imprisoned and the sheets of the "great" Bible for Cromwell were 
destroyed.
*518  $a1538
*651  $a8023
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800605
*10010$a[Various]
*24510$aThe Bible
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Inquisitorial Index of Valentia
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1551 Spain : The 
Inquisitorial Index of Valentia forbade Bibles in Spanish or any other 
vernacular. 1554 The Inquisitorial Index of Valladolid listed 103 
editions of the Bible condemned because of errors and heresies to 
suppression, correction or cancellation.
*518  $a1551
*651  $a8045
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800606
*10010$a[Various]
*24510$aThe Bible
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1555 England : A 
proclamation by Queen Mary commanded "that no manners of persons 
presume to bring into this real any messages., books, paper, etc. in 
the name of Martin Luther, John Calvin, Miles Coverdale, Erasmus, 
Tyndale etc. or any like books containing false doctrines against the 
Catholic faith". 1611 England : Copyright in the King James Version 
rests perpetually in the Crown. Permission to reprint has been given to 
Oxford, Cambridge, Eyre & Spottiswoode and William Collins. 1631 
England : In the edition of 1,000 copies of the Bible printed by R. 
Barker and assigns of Peter Bill the word "not" was omitted from the 
seventh commandment. 1611 England : Because of the Crown copyright, no 
authorized Bible in English was printed in what is now the United 
States until after the Revolution. 1631 England : The printers were 
heavily fined and the edition so vigorously suppressed that few copies 
have survived. It was named the "Wicked Bible".
*518  $a1555, 1611
*518  $a1631
*651  $a8051
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800607
*10010$a[Various]
*24510$aThe Bible
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1560 Switzerland : The 
Geneva or "Breeches Bible" went into 140 editions between 1560 and 
1644, although it was forbidden in the churches. 1624 Germany : The 
Bible translated by Martin Luther in 1534 which had been the most 
widely read book in the country was condemned to flames by Papal 
authority.
*518  $a1560, 1624
*651  $a8047
*651  $a8025
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800608
*10010$a[Various]
*24510$aThe Bible
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Pope Leo XIII, Soviet authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1900 Italy-Rome : Pope Leo 
XIII decreed that translations of the Bible in the vernacular were 
permitted only if approved by the Holy See. 1926 Soviet Union : 
Official directions to libraries stated "The section on religion must 
obtain solely anti-religious books. Religiously dogmatic books such as 
the Gospel, the Koran, the Talmud, etc. must be left in the large 
libraries, but removed from smaller ones". 1926 Soviet Union : Import 
of the Bible not permitted. 1956 Soviet Union : The Bible published 
after a lapse of 38 years.
*518  $a1900, 1926
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8050
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800609
*041  $alat
*10010$aAbelard, Peter
*24510$aIntroductio ad Theologiam
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. [New York Public Library]
*505  $aDescription of the work: Peter Abelard was a theologist; whose 
best known works, Introductio ad Theologiam and Sic et Non explored and 
attempted to reconcile Aristotle, the Bible and reason with faith.
*506  $bCensoring body: Christian Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The Church claimed that 
the texts were contrary to orthodoxy. Beginning in 1120, his books were 
burnt several times. At the Council of Sens in 1142 his entire 
theological work was declared heretical. Further censoring occurred 
upon the inclusion of his writings in the Roman Indexes of 1559 and 
1564. U.S. Customs maintained a ban of his work until 1930.
*518  $a1059-1142
*518  $a1559, 1930
*651  $a8000
*651  $a6357
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800610
*041  $alat
*10010$aAbelard, Peter
*24510$aSic et Non
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
[New York Public Library]
*505  $aDescription of the work: Peter Abelard was a theologist; whose 
best known works, Introductio ad Theologiam and Sic et Non explored and 
attempted to reconcile Aristotle, the Bible and reason with faith.
*506  $bCensoring body: Christian Church, U.S. Customs
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The Church claimed that 
the texts were contrary to orthodoxy. Beginning in 1120, his books were 
burnt several times. At the Council of Sens in 1142 his entire 
theological work was declared heretical. Further censoring occurred 
upon the inclusion of his writings in the Roman Indexes of 1559 and 
1564. U.S. Customs maintained a ban of his work until 1930.
*518  $a1059-1142
*518  $a1559, 1930
*651  $a8000
*651  $a6357
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned

*10010$aAbelard, Pierre [1079-1142]
*24510$aIntroductio ad Theologiam
*260  $c1120
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: dialectical analysis of the mystery of 
God and the Trinity.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1120, in France-Soissons: 
A provincial synod charged Abelard with religious heresy. Results of 
incident 1120, Soissons, France: Abelard was forced to burn his 
"Introductio ad Theologiam and was imprisoned in the convent of 
St-Medard. 1140, Rome, Italy: All works banned by the Council at Sens 
and ordered burned by Pope Innocent III. St-Benard called Abelard "an 
infernal dragon and the precursor of the Anti-Christ." 1559 and 1564: 
"All writing placed on the "Index librorum prohibitorum"

*10010$aAbelard, Pierre [1079-1142]
*24510$aLettres d'Heloi et Abelard
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon

*505  $aDescription of the work: collection of love letters and 
religious correspondence between Heloise and Abelard.

*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1120, in France-Soissons:

9800613
*10010$a[Various]
*24510$aThe Talmud
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Dominicans, Franciscans, Pope Clement IV, the 
Inquisition, USSR State
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1190 Egypt-Cairo: With 
his "Guide for the Perplexed", Maimonides, the Jewish philosopher, 
aroused the Christian's resentment. 1244 France-Paris: "Talmud" burned 
on charges of blasphemy and immorality. The book was persecuted in 
various places for another 100 years. 1244 Italy-Rome: Pope Clement IV 
appointed a committee of censors who expunged all passages that 
appeared derogatory of Christianity. (Talmudic references to ancient 
paganism were widely misrepresented as criticism of the Church.) 1926 
Soviet Union: Official directions to libraries stated "The section on 
religion must obtain solely anti-religious books. Religiously dogmatic 
books such as the 'Gospel', the 'Koran', the 'Talmud', etc. must be 
left in the large libraries, but removed from smaller ones. Results of 
incident: 1190 Egypt-Cairo: First official burning of Hebrew books by 
orders of Dominicans, Franciscans, and others. 1490 Spain-Salamanca: 
In an auto-da-fe, thousands of Hebrew books including biblical texts 
were burned by order of the Inquisition. 1926 Soviet Union: virtually 
no printing of the work since then.

delivered to the Inquisition for correction.

*10010$aDante, Alighieri [1265-1321]
*24510$aDe Monarchia
*260  $c1310-1313
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Treatise of political philosophy in 
Latin and arranged in three books composed in the years immediately 
following the arrival of Henry VII in Italy.
*506  $bCensoring body: Ruling King, Savonarola, Pope Paul IV, The 
Index of Trent, The Inquisition
$eReason for censorship: religious
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1318 France-Lombardy: "De 
Monarchia" was publicly burned. 1559 Italy-Rome: "De Monarchia" banned 
by Pope Paul IV and the Index of Trent for asserting that the authority 
of Kings was derived from God, not through God's Vicar on earth, the 
Pope. 1497 Italy-Florence: Works burned by Savonarola in the "Bonfire 
of the vanities".

9800617
*10010$aSchedel, Hartmann [1410-1485]
*24510$aNuremberg Chronicle
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Great illustrated history of the world 
includes (plate CLXIX), a picture of the female Pope Joan and her baby, 
here said to have succeeded as "John VIII" on the death of Leo IV who 
died in 855.
*506  $bCensoring body: Pope Clement VI
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1400 Italy-Sienne: An 
image of Pope Joan was included among the images of most of the Popes 
in Sienne Cathedral. Results of incident: 1493 Italy-Rome: the legend 
was generally believed, but the earlier doubts became more general, and 
the picture and account of Joan were piously inked over or cut out of 
many copies of this and other books. There has been much controversy as 
to the truth of the legend, and it is now generally thought to be 
false. 1600 Italy-Rome: at the request of Pope Clement VI, her name was 
changed to Pope Zachary.

9800618
*10010$aSavonarola, Girolamo [1452-1498]
*24510$aSavonarola's Writings
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Writings by Savonarola Dominican, a 
monk and spiritual reformer, who demanded church reforms and denounced 
papal corruption.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1497 Italy-Florence: 
Savonarola attempted to turn the pleasure loving Florentines from their 
"pagan" ways and turned the annual carnival into a "burning of the 
vanities", including works by Ovid, Propertius and Boccaccio. Results 
of incident: 1498 Italy: He was forced by tortures on the rack to 
confess his heresy in demanding church reforms and in denouncing papal 
corruptions. After the ceremonial of degradation, he was hung on a 
cross and burned with all his writings, sermons, essays, and pamphlets.

9800619
*041  $aeng
*10010$aMilton, John [1608-1674]
*24510$aAreopagitica
$bA Speech for the Liberty of Unlicenc'd Printing, to the Parliament of 
England
*260  $c1644
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: A Speech for the Liberty of Unlicenc'd 
Printing, to the Parliament of England", 1644: a call on the astronomer 
Galileo who was in semi-captivity because of the Roman Church. A famed 
eloquent plea for freedom of the pen.
*506  $bCensoring body: Cromwell and the Parliament of Protestant 
England
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1476, England: Shortly 
after Caxton set up his press in Westminster, the crown forbade all 
printing except by Royal permission. This prelicensing continued for 
nearly 200 years, eventually calling forth the "Areopagitica, ..." 
1644: "Areopagitica, _" was delivered before parliament and was 
published without license in defiance of a restraining ordinance. 1644, 
England: "Areopagitica, _" was condemned by Cromwell and the Parliament 
of Protestant England for such sentences as this: "And yet on the other 
hand unless wariness be used, as good almost kill a man as kill a good 
Booke... who destroys a good Booke, kills Reason itself, kills the 
Image of God as it were in the eye." 1695, England: Precensorship of 
the press abolished and never again enforced.
*518  $a1644
*651  $a8051
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^

*10010$aMilton, John [1608-1674]
*24510$aEikonoklastes
*260  $c1649

*505  $aDescription of the work: self portrait of the Royal Saint 
Martyr, catching the public in its first shock of horror over the 
execution of Charles I, was one of the most potent pieces of propaganda 
in English history.
*506  $bCensoring body: Parliament of Protestant England
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1660, England: 
"Eikonoklastes" was burned by the common hangman at the time of 
Restoration for attacking the hypocrisy of the religion of Charles I, 
and for arguing against the divine right of kings.

England: "Pro Populo Anglicano Defensio" was publicly burned. In the 
case of "Eikonoklastes" the author escaped the scaffold only through 
the influence of friends.

9800624
*041  $aeng
*10010$aWilliams, Roger
*24510$aThe Bloudy Tenent of Persecution
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
[New York Public Library]
*505  $aDescription of the work: Roger Williams was an outspoken 
advocate of religious freedom, and was one of the first challengers of 
Puritan Theocracy
*506  $bCensoring body: Massachusetts Bay Colony
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Williams was banished from 
the Massachusetts Bay Colony for his toleration and support for 
religious diversity, which included, "Jews, Pagans, and Turks." His 
defiance over state control over religious freedom led to his expulsion 
from the state. Williams moved to Rhode Island and founded the city of 
Providence. In 1644, Williams wrote a book on religious freedom, 
democracy and intellectual freedom, The Bloudy Tenent of Persecution. 
Results of incident In 1936, 300 years after Williams expulsion from 
the former colony , the state legislature retracted its expulsion order.
*518  $a1635-1936
*651  $a6357
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800625
*041  $aeng
*10010$aZenger, John Peter
*24510$aThe New York Weekly Journal
$ca newspaper
*260  $aNew York, Colonial America
$bJohn Peter Zenger
$c1734
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
[The First Freedom Today, R. Downs, ALA,Chicago, 1984 Pg.5]
*505  $aDescription of the work: John Peter Zenger published the 
newspaper The New York Weekly Journal, a newspaper in direct opposition 
to the government paper, the New York Weekly Gazette. The newspaper 
published articles concerned with the government and liberty of the 
press. The issues the British Government were concerned with were 
described "as having in them many things tending to raise seditions and 
tumults among the people of this province, and to fill their minds with 
contempt for his majesty's government."
*506  $bCensoring body: British Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "...In October 1734 a 
committee was appointed to investigate Zenger's newspaper and to look 
into the charges of seditious libel that had been alleged against it. 
The committee found numbers 7,47, 48, and 49, which contained (a 
reprinted article on the liberty of the press), to be libelous as 
charged and ordered them to be burned. Zenger was arrested and 
jailed. Results of incident: The Zenger case was one of the last of its 
kind to be held before the American Revolution. The case set a precedent 
for many trials to come concerning freedom of the press and speech.
*518  $a1735
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a6357
*651  $a8051
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800626
*041  $aita
*10010$aAretino, Pietro [1492-1556]
*24510$aSonnetti Lussuriosi
$cLa Corona di Cazza
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and Village Voice, Onan the Barbarian, October 19, 1993
*505  $aDescription of the work: Pietro Aretino's book Sonetti 
Lussuriosi, (otherwise known as La Corona di Cazza) contained 
illustrations of various sexual positions, "Posizioni".
*506  $bCensoring body: Catholic Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: In 1527 Pope Clement VII 
condemned and had suppressed every edition of his Sonetti Lussuriosi 
which had been published in 1524. Results of incident: In 1558, the 
book went on the Vatican's first index of forbidden books.

9800627
*041  $afre
*10010$aRabelais, Francois [1494-1553]
*24510$aPantagruel
$bGargentua
*260  $c1533
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: The story of Pantagruel, the giant, 
son of Gargentua, their feats, their wars and adventures.
*506  $bCensoring body: The divines of the Sorbonne, French parliament, 
U.S. Custom Department, South African State
$eReason for censorship: Political
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1533 France: The first of 
two parts of "Pantagruel", published without the knowledge of the 
author, were listed on the "Index" of the Sorbonne and on the Official 
black list of parliament. 1546 France: The Third book of "Pantagruel" 
was published under the author's name "avec privilege du Roi". 1564 
Italy-Rome: The "Index" listed Rabelais in its severe first class as 
"Rebelisius". Results of incident: 1535 Italy-Rome: A Papal bull 
absolved Rabelais from ecclesiastical censure. 1552 France: Taking 
advantage of the King's absence from Paris, the divines of the Sorbonne 
censored the fourth book on publication. 1554 France: Cardinal de 
Chatillon persuaded Henry II to raise the ban on the works of Rabelais. 
1930 United States: The customs Department lifted the ban on all 
editions with the exception of those with so-called obscene 
illustrations, specifically Frank C. Pape's drawings for an edition of 
the Motteux translation. 1938 South Africa-Johannesburg: All works 
banned.
*518  $a1533-1938
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8052
*651  $a5458
*651  $a6357
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800628
*041  $aita
*10010$aMachiavelli, Niccolo [1469-1527]
*24510$aDiscorsi
*260  $c1503
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Pope Paul IV, Clement VIII
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1555 Italy-Rome: Although 
Machiavelli had been the ambassador and advisor of Popes and Cardinals 
in his days, Pope Paul IV placed his works in the severest category of 
the "Index," and Clement VIII made a fresh prohibition of a Lausanne 
edition of his "Discorsi".
*518  $a1555
*651  $a8052
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800629
*041  $aita
*10010$aMachiavelli, Niccolo [1469-1527]
*24510$aIl Principe
*260  $c1513
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Pope Paul IV, Huguenot Gentillet, The 
Elizabethans
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1555 Italy-Rome: Although 
Machiavelli had been the ambassador and advisor of Popes and Cardinals 
in his days, Pope Paul IV placed his works in the severest category of 
the "Index," and Clement VIII made a fresh prohibition of a Lausanne 
edition of his "Discorsi". 1576 France: Selected maxims from "Il 
Principe" translated into French, were attacked by the Huguenot 
Gentillet for their political views. Cesare Borgia was supposed to have 
been the "Prince". Results of incident: 1602 England: The Elizabethans 
derived from Gentillet their idea of and hostility for "Il Principe". 
1935 Italy: In Fascist thinking, "Il Principe" demonstrated disjointed 
Italy's need for an all-powerful dictator supported by a national army. 
Mussolini paid Machiavelli tribute by encouraging the distribution of 
"Il Principe" in thousands of cheap copies.
*518  $a1555, 1576
*518  $a1602
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8051
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800630
*10010$aLuther, Martin [1483-1546]
*24510$aWorks
*260  $c1520
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Luther stated the causes of social 
discontent. Luther's Ninety-Five theses (posted 1517), an attack on various 
ecclesiastical abuses, precipitated the Reformation which soon spread 
over northern Europe and later over much of the world through 
Protestant Missions. His personal discovery of the doctrine of 
"justification by faith" alone led to a reformation of medieval 
doctrine and along with other factors led to the rise of the Protestant 
churches.
*506  $bCensoring body: Theological faculties of Cologne and Louvain, Pope Leo X
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1517 Germany-Wittenberg: 
Luther nailed 95 theses, criticizing the use of indulgences, to the 
door of the Castle Church at the University. 1521 Italy-Rome: A Papal 
bull by Leo X excommunicated Luther, and forbade printing, selling, 
reading or quoting, his "Works". 1521 Germany: Charles V, on his own 
authority, issues an edict against Luther. Results of incident: 1517 
The Theological faculties of Louvain and Cologne ordered copies of the 
theses to be burned on grounds of heresy. 1519 Defending his theses in 
debate, Luther was forced to declare his differences with the Church. 
1521 France: The theological faculties of the University of Paris 
ordered the "Theses" burned. 1521 Italy-Rome: The Papal bull by Leo X 
against Luther's "Works" created a passionate interest in them. In 
three months 4,000 copies of "Address to the German Nobility", were 
sold; in five days 5,000 copies of the vernacular edition of the New 
Testament were sold. He also ordered a formal burning of Luther's 
effigy and books.
*518  $a1517-1521
*651  $a8025
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8023
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800631
*10010$aLuther, Martin [1483-1546]
*24510$aAddress to the German Nobility
*260  $c1520
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Luther stated the causes of social 
discontent. Luther's Ninety-Five theses (posted 1517), an attack on various 
ecclesiastical abuses, precipitated the Reformation which soon spread 
over northern Europe and later over much of the world through 
Protestant Missions. His personal discovery of the doctrine of 
"justification by faith" alone led to a reformation of medieval 
doctrine and along with other factors led to the rise of the Protestant 
churches.
*506  $bCensoring body: Theological faculties of Cologne and Louvain, Pope Leo X
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1517 Germany-Wittenberg: 
Luther nailed 95 theses, criticizing the use of indulgences, to the 
door of the Castle Church at the University. 1521 Italy-Rome: A Papal 
bull by Leo X excommunicated Luther, and forbade printing, selling, 
reading or quoting, his "Works". 1521 Germany: Charles V, on his own 
authority, issues an edict against Luther. Results of incident: 1517 
The Theological faculties of Louvain and Cologne ordered copies of the 
theses to be burned on grounds of heresy. 1519 Defending his theses in 
debate, Luther was forced to declare his differences with the Church. 
1521 France: The theological faculties of the University of Paris 
ordered the "Theses" burned. 1521 Italy-Rome: The Papal bull by Leo X 
against Luther's "Works" created a passionate interest in them. In 
three months 4,000 copies of "Address to the German Nobility", were 
sold; in five days 5,000 copies of the vernacular edition of the New 
Testament were sold. He also ordered a formal burning of Luther's 
effigy and books.
*518  $a1517-1521
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8025
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800632
*041  $aeng
*10010$aCalvin, John [1509-1564]
*24510$aCivil and Canonical Law
*260  $c1542
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Reformed Protestantism doctrine. 
Theologian, ecclesiastical statesman and one of the most important 
Protestant Reformers.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Sorbonne, Queen Mary, Catholic Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1542 France: "Civil and 
Canonical Law" forbidden by the Sorbonne. 1555 England: Queen Mary's 
proclamation required "that no manner of persons presume to bring into 
the realm any manuscripts, books, papers, by John Calvin . . . 
containing false doctrine against the Catholic faith" 1559 and 1564 
Italy-Rome: All works listed for heresy in the first class prohibition 
of the "Index."
*518  $a1542, 1555
*518  $a1559, 1564
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8051
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800633
*10010$aPaine, Thomas
*24510$aThe Age of reason
*260  $c1792-1795
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and Encyclopedia of Censorship, Jonathon Green,Pg. 3-4
*505  $aDescription of the work: "...The Age of Reason was written 
between 1792-1795 while Paine was in prison for his opposition to the 
execution of Louis XIV."
*506  $bCensoring body: Christian Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: In was condemned as 
blasphemous and joined Paine's other work as a target for the censor. 
Results of incident: No copies survive.
*518  $a1759
*651  $a8023
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800634
*041  $afre
*10010$aMontaigne, Michel de [1533-1592]
*24510$aLes Essaies
*260  $c1580-1588
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Written more perhaps to express his 
views the first two books of "Essays" include 94 chapters; the earliest 
are short, relatively impersonal strings of anecdotes with brief 
conclusions.
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1595 France-Lyons: Certain 
sections of the unexpurgated edition were banned by the Church for 
being tolerant of an easy morality. 1676 Italy-Rome: Listed in the Index
*506  $bCensoring body: Church
*518  $a1595, 1676
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8052
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800635
*041  $aeng
*10010$aScott, Reginald (c.1538-1599)
*24510$aA Discovery of Witchcraft
*260  $c1584
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: King James I
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1584 England-London: The 
author held that the prosecution of those accused of witchcraft was 
contrary to the dictates of reason as well as of religion, and he 
placed the responsibility at the door of the Roman Church. Results of 
incident 1584, England-London: all obtainable copies were burned on the 
accession of James I in 1603 and those remaining are now rare. 1586: A 
decree of the Star Chamber greatly tightened the censorship laws.
*518  $a1584
*651  $a8051
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800636
*041  $aeng
*10010$aStubbs, John [c.1543-1591]
*24510$aThe Discoverie of a Gaping Gulf Where into England is Likely to 
be Swallowed by another French Marriage
*260  $c1579
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: An attack on the proposed marriage of 
Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Anjou.
*506  $bCensoring body: Royalty
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1579 England-London: The 
copies of the book were burned in the kitchen stove of Stationer's 
Hall. The author was condemned to have his right hand cut off by means 
of a cleaver driven through the wrist by a mallet. Stubbs thereupon 
raised his hat with his left hand and cried, "God save the Queen".
*518  $a1579
*651  $a8051
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800637
*041  $aeng
*10010$aParsons, Robert [1546-1610]
*24510$aA Conference about the Next Succession to the Crown of England
*260  $c1594
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: The intention of the book was to 
support the title of the Infanta against that of James I, after the 
death of Queen Elizabeth.
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1603 London, England: 
The book was rigorously suppressed by Parliament, which enacted that 
"whosoever should be found to have it in their house should be guilty 
of high treason." 1603 England-London: The printer is said to have been 
hanged, drawn, and quartered.
*506  $bCensoring body: Parliament
*518  $a1603
*651  $a8051
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
*70010$aCardinal Allen
*70010$aEnglefield, Sir Francis
^
9800638
*041  $aita
*10010$aGalilei, Galileo [1564-1642]
*24510$aDialogo sopra i due Massimi Sistemi del Mondo
$bEnglish title: Dialogue concerning the Two Chief World Systems 
Ptolemaic and Copernican
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: The book "Dialogue" concerning the two 
chief world systems Ptolemaic and Copernican is an unabashed plea for 
Copernican system. Copernican theory, movement of the spots across the 
face of the sun, Galileo maintained, proved Copernicus was right and 
Ptolemy wrong.
*506  $bCensoring body: Pope Paul IV, Pope Urban VIII
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1616, Rome, Italy: Galileo 
was reprimanded by Pope Paul IV, and told not to "hold, teach or 
defend" the condemned doctrine of Copernicus, whose theory he had tried 
to reconcile with religion. 1633: "Dialogo" banned by Pope Urban VIII 
for heresy and breach of good faith. The author was examined by the 
Inquisition under threat of torture and sentenced to incarceration at 
the pleasure of the Tribunal. 
Galileo, although a white-haired old man of 70, was compelled to kneel, 
clothed in sackcloth, and deny that which he knew to be true. He 
promised "that he would never again in words or writing spread this 
damnable heresy." He is said to have murmured as he rose from his 
knees; "Nevertheless it does move." By way of penance he was enjoined 
to recite once a week for three years the seven penitential psalms, 
although he felt "that Holy Writ was intended to teach men how to go to 
Heaven, not how the heavens go". 1642: On Galileo's death, his 
common-law wife submitted his manuscripts on telescopic and pendulum 
inventions to her confessor who subsequently destroyed them as 
heretical.
*518  $a1616, 1633
*651  $a8033
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800639
*041  $aeng
*10010$aShakespeare, William [1564-1616]
*24510$aThe Tragedy of King Richard the Second
*260  $c1597
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Queen Elizabeth, Thomas Bowdler
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1597 England: The original 
edition, contained a scene in which the King was deposed, and it so 
infuriated Queen Elizabeth that she ordered it eliminated from all 
copies. 1597 England: Queen Elizabeth complained that the play had been 
acted forty times in streets and houses "for the encouragement of 
disaffection." 1601 Sir Gilly Merrick paid players 40 shillings to 
revive the play on the afternoon when the Earl of Essex sought to rouse 
London against the Queen. 1608 England: The scene was not reinserted 
until after the death of Queen Elizabeth, in the edition of 1608. 1818 
Thomas Bowdler, M.D., published the "Family Shakespeare" omitting 
"those words and expressions which cannot with propriety be read aloud 
in the family." "Bowdlerize" thereupon became synonymous with 
"expurgate."
*518  $a1597, 1818
*651  $a8051
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
^
9800640
*041  $aeng
*10010$aShakespeare, William [1564-1616]
*24510$aThe Merchant of Venice
*260  $c1600
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Thomas Bowdler, Jewish organizations
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1818 Thomas Bowdler, M.D., 
published the "Family Shakespeare" omitting "those words and 
expressions which cannot with propriety be read aloud in the family." 
"Bowdlerize" thereupon became synonymous with "expurgate." 1931 United 
States: "The Merchant of Venice" was eliminated from the high school 
curricula of Buffalo and Manchester, New York. Jewish organizations 
believed that it fostered intolerance. 1953: Minority groups still felt 
that Shylock was depicted as an unfortunate characterization of a Jew 
and sought the suppression of the play.
*518  $a1818, 1931
*518  $a1953
*651  $a6357
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
^
9800641
*041  $aeng
*10010$aShakespeare, William [1564-1616]
*24510$aKing Lear
*260  $c1608
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: English Royalty
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1788: "King Lear" was 
prohibited on the English stage until 1820, probably out of respect to 
King George III's acknowledged insanity, when the royal duties were 
transferred to a Regent.
*518  $a1788 - 1820

*691  $aPolitical

9800642
*041  $afre
*10010$aDescartes, Rene [1596-1650]
*24510$aLes Meditations Methaphysiques
$bTreatise on Copernican beliefs
*260  $c1641
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Jesuits, Catholic Church, Soviet authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1633, Holland: Descartes, 
a devoted Catholic, abandoned his treatise on Copernican beliefs when 
he learned that Galileo's treatise had been suppressed in Rome for 
supporting Copernicus's hypothesis of the earth revolving around the 
sun. Rome, Italy: Through the influence of Jesuits, this author's work 
containing Copernican theories were placed on the Index, and forbidden 
in many institution of learning until corrected or expurgated. Results 
of incident: 1665 Italy-Rome: "Les Meditations Methaphysiques" was 
placed on the Index until corrected, as the whole system was opposed of 
Aristotle. 1926 Soviet Union: All philosophical works suppressed. 1948 
Italy-Rome: "Les Meditations Methaphysiques" and six other books 
remained on the Index.
*518  $a1633-1948
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8038
*651  $a8050
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800643
*041  $afre
*10010$aMoliere (Jean-Baptiste Poquelin) (1622-1673)
*24510$aLe Tartuffe ou l'Imposteur
*260  $c1664-1669
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: A satire on religious hypocrisy
*505  $aDescription and results of incident: 1664, France: "Le Tartuffe 
ou l'Imposteur" banned from the public stage by Louis XIV who, 
nevertheless, read it aloud to an audience which included high 
dignitaries of the Church. 1667: While the King was away in Flanders, 
the play was given as "The Impostor." Results of incident:  1664, 
France: The first three acts were given repeatedly at court, but 
Moliere could not get permission for a public performance. During these 
years the church called him "a demon in human flesh," closed his 
theater, and tore down his posters. 1667: The theater was ordered 
closed by the Chief of Police, and the Archbishop of Paris laid a ban 
of excommunication on all who might act in the play, read it, or see 
it. 1669: Permission was granted by the King to perform the play in 
public.
*506  $bCensoring body: King Louis XIV, Chief of Police of Paris, 
Archbishop of Paris
*518  $a1664
*651  $a8023
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800644
*041  $afre
*10010$aPascal, Blaise [1623-1662]
*24510$aLettres a un Provincial
*260  $c1656-1657
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: written in defense of Antoine Arnauld 
an opponent of the Jesuits and defender of Jansenism who was on trial 
before the faculty of theology in Paris.
*506  $bCensoring body: King Louis XIV
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1657 France: "Lettres a un 
Provincial" burned for being too free with the dignity of all secular 
authorities. 1660: Pascal converted to Jansenist teaching and his 
"Lettres a un Provincial" aroused a storm of controversy because of 
their anti-Jesuit flavor. Results of incident: 1660, France: Louis XIV 
ordered that the book "Lettres a un Provincial" "be torn up and burned 
at the "Croix du Tiroir" at the hands of the High Executioner, 
fulfillment of which is to be certified to his Majesty within the week; 
and that meanwhile all printers, booksellers, vendors and others, of 
whatever rank or station, are explicitly prohibited from printing, 
selling, and distributing, and even from having in their possession the 
said book... under pain of public (exemplary) punishment."
*518  $a1657, 1660
*651  $a8023
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800645
*041  $afre
*10010$aPascal, Blaise [1623-1662]
*24510$aPensees
*260  $c1670
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: work of Christian apologetics as a 
consequence of his meditations on miracles and other proofs of 
Christianity. The work remained unfinished at his death.
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1789 Rome, Italy: "Pensee" 
placed on the Index "avec les notes de M.Voltaire."
*506  $bCensoring body: Catholic Church
*518  $a1789
*651  $a8052
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned

9800646
*041  $afre
*10010$aMontesquieu, Baron Charles Louis [1686-1755]
*24510$aLettres Persanes
*260  $c1721
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: a satire on the social, political, 
ecclesiastical, and literary follies of the day.
*506  $bCensoring body: Fleury of the Academy Francaise, Catholic Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1721, France: "Lettres 
Persanes" was published anonymously. 1721, France: "Lettres Persanes" 
shocked Fleury. Montesquieu was not admitted to the Academy until seven 
years after the publication. 1721 Rome, Italy: "Lettres Persanes" 
listed on the Index, where it remained until 1948.
*518  $a1721-1948

9800647
*041  $afre
*10010$aMontesquieu, Baron Charles Louis [1686-1755]
*24510$aL'Esprit des Lois
*260  $c1748
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: the author denounces the abuse of the 
French monarchical system. This work is one of the great works in the 
history of political theory and in the history of jurisprudence.
*506  $bCensoring body: Catholic Church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1751, France: The Sorbonne 
planned but did not carry out a regular censure of the author for his 
book "L'Esprit des Lois." 1751 Italy-Rome: "L'Esprit des Lois", 
prohibited by the church authorities, although not with the entire 
approval of the Pope.
*518  $a1751
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8052

*691  $aPolitical

^
9800648
*041  $aeng
*10010$aCleland, John [1709-1789]
*24510$aMemoirs of a Woman of Pleasure, also known as Fanny Hill
*260  $c1749
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: an elegant flowery work of pornography 
describing the activities of a London prostitute. This novel enjoyed 
enormous popularity.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Privy Council, The State of Massachusetts
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1749, England: Arraigned 
before the Privy Council for writing a literary obscenity, Cleland 
pleaded poverty. 1821, United States: Banned in Massachusetts in the 
first known obscenity case in the U.S. Results of incident:1749, 
England: Cleland was reprimanded and given a pension of 100 pounds 
annually on condition that he not repeat the offense. The book went 
underground and remained the chief erotic classic for more than 200 
years. 1963, United States: Published openly by Grove Press, the book 
was attacked by "decency" groups. The highest courts of New Jersey and 
Massachusetts declared it obscene; on March 21, 1966, the U.S. Supreme 
Court reversed the unfavorable judgments, clearing "Memoirs of a Woman 
of Pleasure, also known as Fanny Hill" for publication. 1965, Illinois: 
Prosecution of the book in Illinois was a major factor in the closing 
of a bookstore, Paul Romaine, Books in Chicago, according to Mr. 
Romaine. During the period when the book was emerging in the open 
market, it was seized in Berlin, burned in Manchester, England and 
burned in Japan.
*518  $a1749-1965
*651  $a8051
*651  $a6357
*651  $a8025
*651  $a7130
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^
9800649
*041  $afre
*10010$aRousseau, Jean-Jacques [1712-1778]
*24510$aJulie, ou la Nouvelle Heloise
*260  $c1761
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Novel of a passion with a broad moral, 
philosophical, religious and even economic context.
*506  $bCensoring body: Catholic Church, Soviet authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1806, Rome, Italy: "Julie, 
ou la Nouvelle Heloise" placed on the Index. 1935, Soviet Union: All 
philosophical works forbidden. 1936: Works permitted in Soviet Union.
*518  $a1806
*518  $a1935-1936
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8050
*691  $aReligious
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned

9800650
*041  $afre
*10010$aRousseau, Jean-Jacques [1712-1778]
*24510$aEmilie, ou de l'Education
*260  $c1762
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: A long reverie about education, 
helping parents to know how to raise their children properly.
*506  $bCensoring body: Parliament of Paris, Catholic Church, Soviet 
authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1762 France: "Emilie, ou 
de l'Education" condemned by the Parliament of Paris to be thorn and 
burned at the foot of the great staircase; The Archbishop published a 
pastoral against the author. 1762, France: Rousseau went in exile to 
Geneva, his birthplace. 1763, Switzerland: Rousseau fled to Neuchatel, 
where he had the protection of Frederick the Great, who was elected 
prince of this Swiss canton as well as King of Prussia. 1763, Rome, 
Italy: Both books placed on the Index. 1935, Soviet Union: All 
philosophical works forbidden. 1936: Works permitted in Soviet Union.
*518  $a1762, 1806
*518  $a1935-1936
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8050
*691  $aReligious
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800651
*041  $afre
*10010$aRousseau, Jean-Jacques [1712-1778]
*24510$aDu contrat Social
*260  $c1762
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Develops the political principles that 
are summarized at the conclusion of "Emilie, ou de l'Education." 
Starting with inequality as an irreversible fact, Rousseau tried to 
answer the question of what compels one man to obey another man or by 
what right does one man exert authority over another.
*506  $bCensoring body: Catholic church, Soviet authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1762, France: Rousseau 
went in exile to Geneva, his birthplace. 1763, Switzerland: Rousseau 
fled to Neuchatel, where he had the protection of Frederick the Great, 
who was elected prince of this Swiss canton as well as King of Prussia. 
1766: "Du contrat Social" and "Lettres a Christophe de Beaumont, 
Archeveque de Paris" placed on the Index. 1935, Soviet Union: All 
philosophical works forbidden. 1936: Works permitted in Soviet Union.
*518  $a1766
*518  $a1935-1936

9800652
*041  $afre
*10010$aRousseau, Jean-Jacques [1712-1778]
*24510$aLettres de Montagne
*260  $c1763
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Attack of the Council and the 
constitution of Geneva and a reply to J.B. Tronchin, procurer general 
of the Geneva Republic, who had ordered burning of "Emilie, ou de 
l'Education" and "Du contrat Social."
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1763 Switzerland: 
Condemned by the Council of Geneva for his "Lettres de Montagne". 1762, 
France: Rousseau went in exile to Geneva, his birthplace. 1763, 
Switzerland: Rousseau fled to Neuchatel, where he had the protection of 
Frederick the Great, who was elected prince of this Swiss canton as 
well as King of Prussia. 1935, Soviet Union: All philosophical works 
forbidden. 1936: Works permitted in Soviet Union.

*041  $afre
*10010$aRousseau, Jean-Jacques (1712-1778)
*24510$aLettres a Christophe de Beaumont, Archeveque de Paris
*260  $c1763
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Rousseau defends himself from an 
attack from the Archbishop of Paris, who had condemned "Emilie, ou de 
l'Education" and "Lettres de Montagne".
*506  $bCensoring body: Catholic church, Soviet authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1762, France: Rousseau 
went in exile to Geneva, his birthplace. 1763, Switzerland: Rousseau

*041  $afre
*10010$aRousseau, Jean-Jacques (1712-1778)
*24510$aConfessions
*260  $c1770
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Rousseau's autobiography
*506  $bCensoring body: U.S. Customs Department, Soviet authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1762, France: Rousseau 
went in exile to Geneva, his birthplace. 1763, Switzerland: Rousseau 
fled to Neuchatel, where he had the protection of Frederick the Great, 
who was elected prince of this Swiss canton as well as King of Prussia. 
1929, United States: "Confessions" was banned by the Customs Department 
as being injurious to public morals. 1935, Soviet Union: All 
philosophical works forbidden. 1936: Works permitted in Soviet Union.

9800655
*041  $afre
*10010$aChamber, Ephraim
*240  $aCyclopedia
*24510$aL'Encyclopedie
$bFrench translation of Ephraim Chamber's "Cyclopedia."
*260  $bLe Breton
$c1751-1780
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Diderot undertook the task with 
mathematician Jean Le Rond d'Alembert as co-editor and profoundly 
changed the nature of the publication, broadening the scope and turning 
it into an important organ of radical and revolutionary opinion. The 
Encyclopedia was to bring out the essential principles and applications 
of every art and sciences.
*506  $bCensoring body: the King's Council, Le Breton, the Catholic 
church
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1752, France: The first 
two volumes were suppressed by the King's Council for political and 
religious outspokenness. Results of incident 1754, France: Louis XV 
issued a privilege for the continuation of the work. 1759: Although 
innocent of treason, this work was looked upon with suspicion and alarm 
in official circles. Consequently, the royal privilege was withdrawn. 
The work, however, was continued surreptitiously by the publisher, Le 
Breton, who had been censoring Dehydrate work without his knowledge. 
For a century and a half, scholars despaired of recovering Diderot's 
original text, for the manuscript had been destroyed as the matter was 
set in type, but about 200 years later a volume containing Le Breton's 
corrections of the proof turned up and was acquired by an American 
collector. 1759 Rome, Italy: The first seven volumes were condemned by 
the Index. 1804 Rome, Italy: The complete work was placed on the Index.
*518  $a1752
*518  $a1759, 1804
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8052
*691  $aReligious
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
*70010$aDiderot, Denis
$d1713-1784
$eEditor
*70010$aLe Rond d'Alembert, Jean
$eCo-editor

9800656
*041  $ager
*10010$aKant, Immanuel (1724-1804)
*24510$aCritique of Pure Reason
*260  $c1781
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: The result of some 10 years of 
thinking and meditation. Kant inaugurated a new era in the development 
of philosophical thought. His comprehensive and systematic work in 
theory of knowledge, ethics, and esthetics greatly influence all 
subsequent philosophy. Divided in two parts: Transcendental Doctrine of 
Elements and Transcendental Doctrine of Method.
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1827, Rome, Italy: 
"Critique of Pure Reason," in Italian, was placed on the Index. 1928, 
Soviet Union: All works banned. 1939, Spain: Franco purged the 
libraries of "such disgraceful writers" as Kant.
*506  $bCensoring body: the Lutheran Prussian State, King Frederick 
William II, Catholic Church, Soviet authorities, Franco
*518  $a1793-1939
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8050
*651  $a8045
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800657
*041  $ager
*10010$aKant, Immanuel (1724-1804)
*24510$aDie Religion Innerhalb der Grenzen der Blossen Vernunft
*260  $c1793
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Dispute with Prussian authorities on 
the right to express religious opinion.
*506  $bCensoring body: Lutheran Prussian State, Frederick William II, 
Soviet authorities, Franco
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1793, Prussia: "Die 
Religion Innerhalb der Grenzen der Blossen Vernunft," second part, was 
suppressed by the strongly Lutheran Prussian State because it was 
opposed to the literal doctrines of the Lutheran Church. Results of 
incident 1793, Kanigsberg: Both parts were published, and Frederick 
William II promptly forbade the author to lecture or write on religion, 
not so much because of his religious unorthodoxly, as for his supposed 
sympathy with French revolutionary ideas. 1928, Soviet Union: All works 
banned. 1939, Spain: Franco purged the libraries of "such disgraceful 
writers" as Kant.
*518  $a1793
*518  $a1928, 1939
*651  $a8025
*651  $a8050
*651  $a8045
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800658
*041  $afre
*10010$aBeaumarchais, Pierre Augustin Caron de (1732-1799)
*24510$aLe Barbier de Seville
*260  $c1773
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Comedie of intrigue in which the 
valet's resourcefulness and cunning were portrayed with definite 
class-conscious sympathy.
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1770-1780, France: During 
his service as a secret agent of Louis XV and Louis XVI, Beaumarchais 
traveled abroad to seize writings condemning Mme. Du Barry and 
Marie-Antoinette. 1773, France: For two years "Le Barbier de Seville" was 
forbidden to be performed on the stage. 1775, France: a revised version 
of "Le Barbier de Seville" was successful and allowed to be performed 
on the stage. 1778: Beaumarchais was imprisoned in St. Lazare. 1792: 
His works were suppressed. Released, he became an emigre for 4 years.
*506  $bCensoring body: French Parliament, Louis XVI
*518  $a1773-1775
*518  $a1792
*651  $a8023
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800659
*041  $afre
*10010$aBeaumarchais, Pierre Augustin Caron de (1732-1799)
*24510$aMemoires
*260  $c1778
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Beaumarchais' life rivals his works as 
drama, controversy, adventure and intrigue. The son of a watchmaker, he 
invented an escapement mechanism and the question of its patent led to 
the first of many legal actions. For his defense in these suits he 
wrote a series of brilliant polemics which made his reputation, though 
he was only partly successful at law.
*506  $bCensoring body: French Parliament, Louis XVI
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1770-1780, France: During 
his service as a secret agent of Louis XV and Louis XVI, Beaumarchais 
traveled abroad to seize writings condemning Mme. Du Barry and 
Marie-Antoinette. 1774, "Memoires" was condemned to flames by 
Parliament for criticizing the state powers. Beaumarchais was 
charged with treason against the Republic. 1778: Beaumarchais was 
imprisoned in St. Lazare. 1792: His works were suppressed. Released, he 
became an emigre for 4 years.
*518  $a1774, 1792
*651  $a8023
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800660
*041  $afre
*10010$aBeaumarchais, Pierre Augustin Caron de (1732-1799)
*24510$aLe Mariage de Figaro
*260  $c1778
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Comedie of intrigue in which the 
valet's resourcefulness and cunning were portrayed with definite 
class-conscious sympathy.
*506  $bCensoring body: Louis XVI
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1770-1780, France: During 
his service as a secret agent of Louis XV and Louis XVI, Beaumarchais 
traveled abroad to seize writings condemning Mme. Du Barry and 
Marie-Antoinette. 1778, "Le Mariage de Figaro" was suppressed for 6 
years by Louis XVI at court and in public performances on the grounds 
of profound immorality. Beaumarchais was charged with treason 
against the Republic. 1778: Beaumarchais was imprisoned in St. Lazare. 
1792: His works were suppressed. Released, he became an emigre for 4 
years.
*518  $a1778, 1792
*651  $a8023

9800661
*041  $aeng
$hfre
*10010$aSade, D.A.F., Marquis de (1740-1814)
*24510$aJustine or the Misfortunes of Virtue
*260  $c1791
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: French authorities, U.S. Customs, The Church, 
British Customs
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1791, France: The 
authorities suppressed "Justine or the Misfortunes of Virtue" and 
"Juliette." 1791, France: The Marquis spent much of his life in prison. 
Grandmothers, misled by the title, are said to have given "Justine or 
the Misfortunes of Virtue" to their frivolous granddaughters to read as 
an object lesson. 1954, Paris, France: A complete edition of the works 
of Sade in 26 volumes, begun in 1947, finally in 1954 came to the 
attention of the Commission Consultative, which under a decree of 1940, 
was empowered to advise the Minister of Justice to initiate 
prosecutions. 1929, United States: "L'Oeuvre du Marquis de Sade," from 
which the term "sadism" was derived, remained on the list of prohibited 
Customs importations, although pirated editions circulated 
surreptitiously within the barrier. 1948, Italy: Books still listed on 
the Index. 1955,Paris, France: Despite such notable witnesses for the 
defense as Jean Cocteau, the publishers were fined and the books 
ordered destroyed, although most of them had long since been sold. 
1962, London, England: "Justine or the Misfortunes of Virtue" seized by 
British Customs. 1965, United States: Many of the suppressed works 
published openly.
*518  $a1791-1962
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8023
*651  $a6357
*651  $a8051
*691  $aPolitical
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned

*506  $bCensoring body: French authorities, U.S. Customs, The Church, 
British Customs
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1791, France: The 
authorities suppressed "Justine or the Misfortunes of Virtue" and 
Juliette." 1791, France: The Marquis spent much of his life in prison. 
1954, Paris, France: A complete edition of the works 
of Sade in 26 volumes, begun in 1947, finally in 1954 came to the

*505  $aDescription of the work: Passion of Werther for a girl safely 
out of reach.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Lutheran authorities, Franco

Sorrows of Werther" was prohibited under strict censorship exercised by 
the Lutheran authorities. 1939, Spain: Franco purged the libraries of

*10010$aGoethe, Johann Wolfgang von (1749-1832)
*24510$aFaust
*260  $c1790
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1808, Berlin, Germany: The 
State authorities suppressed the production of "Faust," until certain 
"dangerous passages" concerning freedom were deleted. 1939, Spain: 
Franco purged the libraries of the works of "such disgraceful writers" 
as Goethe.

*041  $aspa
*10010$aMolinos, Miguel de
*24510$aGuia Espiritual
$bEnglish title: Spiritual Guide
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
[Valentin Roma]
*505  $aDescription of the work: All of his work was censored, but 
specifically "Guia Espiritual" ("Spiritual Guide") and "Defensa de la 
Contemplacion" ("Defense of Contemplation").
*506  $bCensoring body: Tribunal de la Santa Inquisicion de Zaragoza y 
Lerida
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: After ten years of his 
works' circulation, he was accused of spiritually manipulating the 
Catholic doctrine. His mystical theories on the contemplation of man 
were unacceptable. The diffusion of his work was not greatly affected, 
despite his censorship.

*041  $aspa
*10010$aNebrija, Elio Antonio de
*24510$a[All works and translations by the author were banned]
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
[Valentin Roma]
*505  $aDescription of the work: His entire body of philologic work and 
translation and his study of sacred scriptures was condemned.
*506  $bCensoring body: Fray Diego de Deza and Cardinal Cisneros
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: He was accused in 1505 of 
having contact with Jews and manipulating texts. Because of his 
friendship with Cardinal Cisneros and the act of dedicating to the 
Catholic Queen of one of his books, allowed for leniency in his 
prosecution. Nevertheless, the dissemination of his work and its 
influence was indirectly controlled.

9800668
*041  $aeng
*10010$aJefferson, Thomas (1743-1826)
*24510$aA Summary View of the Rights of British America Set Forth in 
Some Resolutions Intended for Inspection of the Present Delegate of the 
People of Virginia, now in Convention. By a Native, and Member of the 
House of Burgesses
*260  $c1774
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: pamphlet on the Rights of British 
America. He says "Our emigration to this country gave England no more 
rights over us than the emigration of the Danes and the Saxons gave to 
the present authorities of their mother country over England."
*506  $bCensoring body: English House of Parliament
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1774 England: These 
writings were printed by sympathetic friends, without Jefferson's 
knowledge. It contained material rejected by the Virginia 
Constitutional Convention. 1774 England: Popular in America, the 
British edition caused the proscription of Jefferson's name by the 
English House of Parliament.
*518  $a1774
*651  $a8051
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned

*10010$aJefferson, Thomas (1743-1826)
*24510$aMelanges Politiques et Philosophiques. Extraits des Memoires et 
de la Correspondence de T. Jefferson
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: English House of Parliament, Nicholas I
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1774 England: These 
writings were printed by sympathetic friends, without Jefferson's 
knowledge. It contained material rejected by the Virginia 
Constitutional Convention. 1774 England: Popular in America, the 
British edition caused the proscription of Jefferson's name by the 
English House of Parliament. 1833 Russia: "Melanges Politiques et 
Philosophiques. Extraits des Memoires et de la Correspondence de T. 
Jefferson" was banned for political reasons under Nicholas I.
