9800670
*041  $arus
*10010$aRadishchev, Alexander (1749-1802)
*24510$aPutishestvie
$bTitle in English: Journey from Petersburg to Moscow
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: a book of travel with the emphasis on 
the evils of serfdom and Tsarist absolutism.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Tsars
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1790 Russia: "Putishestvie"
was one of the most famous books suppressed by the Tsars. Catherine II 
declared that the book was an attempt to propagate the ideas of the 
French Revolution. 1790 Russia: Catherine II ordered the edition of 
"Putishestvie" to be burned by the public executioner. The author was 
sentenced to death, but the sentence was commuted to ten years in Siberia.
*518  $a1790
*651  $a8064
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800671
*041  $afre
*10010$aHugo, Victor Marie
*24510$aMarion Delorme
$bplay
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: The play "Marion Delorme" is about a 
French courtisan famous for her beauty and her many prestigious lovers. 
The play criticizes the King's ancestor Louis XIII.
*506  $bCensoring body: Official censors of the King Charles X
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Performance of the play, 
Marion Delorme, was prohibited by the official censors because it 
showed Louis XIII as a "weak, superstitious and cruel prince", and this 
depiction might provoke public maleviolence and lead to the 
disparagement of Charles X. Hugo appealed to the King. A royal veto 
sustained the prohibition; but Charles offered to raise the poet's 
pension from 2,000 to 6,000 francs. After Charles was removed by the 
Revolution of 1830, the play was produced at the Theatre Francais and 
published for the first time, in 1831.
*518  $a1829-1831
*651  $a8023
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800672
*041  $afre
*10010$aHugo, Victor Marie
*24510$aLe Roi s'amuse
*260  $c1832
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and Censures, Editions Centre G. Pompidou, Paris, 1987
*505  $aDescription of the work: Set in Renaissance France and 
depicting the frivolous love affairs of Francis I, while antithetically 
revealing the noble character of his court jester.
*506  $bCensoring body: Prime Minister Mr. Guizot
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "Le Roi s'amuse" was 
prohibited after the first performance, by order of the Prime Minister, 
Guizot, for derogatory allusions to the King Louis-Philippe. The ban 
occured only two years after the proclamation of the Charte of 
Abolition of Censorship. During the law suit, Hugo became the ardent 
defensor of freedom of expression and fought the first public battle 
against censorship. In a spectacular address to the court he denounced 
the abusive power of authorities to "confiscate freedom". The ban was 
lifted 50 years later and the play was produced under the supervision 
of the author.
*518  $a1832
*651  $a8023
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800673
*041  $afre
*10010$aBalzac, Honore de (1799-1850)
*24510$aLa Comedie Humaine
*260  $c1831-1847
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: His vast life work was arranged under 
the title in which he claimed at once to be a philosopher, explaining 
man to himself, a historian or "secretary" of society and a sociologist 
and psychologist.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church, Russian State, Franco
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1841: Rome, Italy: All 
works listed on the Index. 1850: Russia: All works banned. 1953, Spain: 
Franco purged the libraries of the works of "such disgraceful writers" 
as Balzac. Soviet Union: Works published in large editions.
*518  $a1841, 1850
*518  $a1953
*651  $a8052

*651  $a8045
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800674
*041  $afre
*10010$aBalzac, Honore de (1799-1850)
*24510$aLes Contes Drolatiques
$bTitle in English: Droll Stories
*260  $c1832-1837
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church, Russian State, Canadian Customs, 
U.S. Customs, Franco
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1841: Rome, Italy: All 
works listed on the Index. 1850: Russia: All works banned. 1914, 
Canada: "Les Contes Drolatiques" (Droll Stories) banned by Customs. 
1930, U.S.A.: Customs ban lifted. 1944, New York City, USA: Concords 
Books, Inc. issued a sale catalogue of 100 including "Les Contes 
Drolatiques" (Droll Stories). They were notified by the Post Office 
Department that the catalogue violated the section relating to mailing 
of obscene literature, and that the title must be blocked out. This was 
done. 1953, Spain: Franco purged the libraries of the works of "such 
disgraceful writers" as Balzac. Soviet Union: Works published in large 
editions.
*518  $a1841, 1850
*518  $a1914-1953
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8064

9800675
*041  $adut
*10010$aHelmers, J. F.
*24510$aDe Hollandsche Natie
$b; Poems
*260  $c1820
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
[Owner of Used Book Shop in Den Haag]
*505  $aDescription of the work: a book of Dutch nationalist poems 
published in 1820
*506  $bCensoring body: French Occupation Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The book was censored 
entirely during the French occupation of the Netherlands due to the 
nationalist nature of the poems.

9800676
*041  $afre
*10010$aDaumier, Honore (1808-1879)
*24510$aLa Caricature
*260  $c1832
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: in 1830 Charles Philipon a liberal 
journalist who had founded the opposition journal "La Caricature" 
invited Daumier to become contributor.
*506  $bCensoring body: The King Louis-Philipe of France
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1832 France: Daumier did a 
satirical drawing of the King Louis-Philipe for which he served six 
months in prison at Ste-Pelagie. The journal was suppressed.
*518  $a1832
$3Journal
*651  $a8023
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800677
*041  $aeng
*10010$aShelley, Percy Bysshe (1792-1822)
*24510$aThe Necessity of Atheism
*260  $c1811
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Oxford University, the Society for the 
Suppression of Vice
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1811 England: Shelley and 
his friend Hogg were dismissed from Oxford as mutineers against 
academic authority, for publishing "The Necessity of Atheism." 
1840-1842 Edward Moxon, a leading publisher, began issuing Shelley's 
works. He and three other publisher-booksellers were prosecuted, partly 
to test if there was one law for "the low booksellers of the Strand" 
and another for more aristocratic ones, who were freely publishing 
books at least as outspoken as 'Queen Mab, a philosophical Poem'." 
1840-1842: Moxon was released, but had to give up all copies of his 
edition. One reason for official hostility to this book in this entire 
period was that it became a basic text for lower and middle-class 
radicals and for the Chartist and Owenite reform movements. The period 
of Shelley's life was an especially repressive one, politically, in 
Britain, a nation badly frightened by the French Revolution.
*518  $a1811-1842
*651  $a8051
*691  $aReligious
*691  $aMoral
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800678
*041  $aeng
*10010$aShelley, Percy Bysshe (1792-1822)
*24510$aQueen Mab, a philosophical Poem
*260  $c1813
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Oxford University, the Society for the 
Suppression of Vice
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: In 1813, at 21 
Shelley had published "Queen Mab, a philosophical Poem" in a very small 
private edition. In 1817 it was cited in his custody trial to show the 
author was an atheist and free-love advocate. In 1821 William Clarke 
issued an edition of "Queen Mab, a philosophical Poem" , and in 1822 he 
was prosecuted by the Society for the Suppression of Vice. 1840-1842 
Edward Moxon, a leading publisher, began issuing Shelley's works. He 
and three other publisher-booksellers were prosecuted, partly to test 
if there was one law for "the low booksellers of the Strand" and 
another for more aristocratic ones, who were freely publishing books at 
least as outspoken as 'Queen Mab, a philosophical Poem'." 1822 England: 
"Queen Mab, a philosophical Poem" could not be copyrighted, and up to 
1845, was pirated in 14 or more editions. In 1821 William Clarke issued 
one of those, and in 1822 he was jailed for four months. Also in the 
1820's, Richard Carlile was jailed for publishing the poem, among 
others. 1840-1842: Moxon was released, but had to give up all copies of 
his edition. One reason for official hostility to this book in this 
entire period was that it became a basic text for lower and 
middle-class radicals and for the Chartist and Owenite reform 
movements. The period of Shelley's life was an especially repressive 
one, politically, in Britain, a nation badly frightened by the French 
Revolution.
*518  $a1811-1842
*651  $a8051
*691  $aReligious
*691  $aMoral
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned

*041  $aeng
*10010$aShelley, Percy Bysshe (1792-1822)
*24510$aAlastor
*260  $c1816
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Oxford University, the Society for the 
Suppression of Vice
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1816 "Alastor" was 
rejected by a library on grounds of immorality. 1840-1842 Edward Moxon, 
a leading publisher, began issuing Shelley's works. He and three other 
publisher-booksellers were prosecuted, partly to test if there was one 
law for "the low booksellers of the Strand" and another for more 
aristocratic ones, who were freely publishing books at least as 
outspoken as 'Queen Mab, a philosophical Poem'." 1840-1842: Moxon was 
released, but had to give up all copies of his edition. One reason for 
official hostility to this book in this entire period was that it 
became a basic text for lower and middle-class radicals and for the 
Chartist and Owenite reform movements. The period of Shelley's life was 
an especially repressive one, politically, in Britain, a nation badly 
frightened by the French Revolution.

9800683
*10010$aHeine, Heinrich (1797-1856)
*24510$aReisebilder
*260  $c1826-1831
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Federal State, The Catholic Church, the Nazi, 
German Democratic State, Soviet occupation authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1833 Germany: The Federal 
Diet issued a decree banning all works by members of a radical group 
called "Young Germany". 1833 Germany: Anticipating such suppression, 
and attracted by the revolution of 1830, Heine had taken up residence 
in Paris in 1831, where he wrote freely and received an annual stipend 
from a fund for political refugees. A Jew, he embraced Christianity in 
1825. 1933 Germany: Works burned in the Nazi bonfires. 1954 German 
Democratic Republic-East Berlin: Works banned by the Soviet occupation 
authorities. Later republished.
*518  $a1833-1954
*651  $a8025
*651  $a8024
*651  $a8052
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800684
*041  $ager
*10010$aHeine, Heinrich (1797-1856)
*24510$aDie Lorelei
*260  $c1827
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Federal State, The Catholic Church, the 
Nazi, German Democratic State, Soviet occupation authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1833 Germany: The Federal 
Diet issued a decree banning all works by members of a radical group 
called "Young Germany". 1833 Germany: Anticipating such suppression, 
and attracted by the revolution of 1830, Heine had taken up residence 
in Paris in 1831, where he wrote freely and received an annual stipend 
from a fund for political refugees. A Jew, he embraced Christianity in 
1825. 1933 Germany: Works burned in the Nazi bonfires. 1939 "Die 
Lorelei" listed as the work of Anonymous instead of Heine, for although 
his works were banned, the poem was too well loved to be suppressed. 
1954 German Democratic Republic-East Berlin: Works banned by the Soviet 
occupation authorities. Later republished.

*24510$aDe la France
*260  $c1835
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship.

*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1833 Germany: The Federal

in Paris in 1831, where he wrote freely and received an annual stipend 
from a fund for political refugees. A Jew, he embraced Christianity in 
1825. 1836 Italy-Rome: "De la France", "Reiseblider", "De l'Allemagne", 
and in 1844 "Neue Gedichte" were placed on the Index, where they 
remained in 1948. 1933 Germany: Works burned in the Nazi bonfires. 1954 
German Democratic Republic-East Berlin: Works banned by the Soviet 
occupation authorities. Later republished.

9800688
*041  $afre
*10010$aHugo, Victor Marie (1802-1885)
*24510$aHernani
*260  $c1830
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Romantic drama, its first performance 
was February 25 1830.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Inspector General of Theaters, Napoleon 
III, The Church, Nicholas I, the French Police
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1830 France-Paris: The 
Inspector General of Theaters ordered the correction of such passages 
in "Hernani" as, "Thinkest thou that kings to me have aught of 
sacredness?" 1850 Russia: All works banned by Nicholas I. 1830 
France-Paris: A literary war ensued: classicists hired professional 
claques. Theophile Gautier organized a troop of volunteers "resolved to 
take their stand upon the rugged mount of Romanticism, and to valiantly 
defend its passes against the assault of the Classics." In the end the 
Romanticism triumphed; but not without a martyr, for a young man died 
fighting a duel over the play "Hernani".
*518  $a1830, 1850
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8064
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800689
*041  $afre
*10010$aHugo, Victor Marie (1802-1885)
*24510$aNotre Dame de Paris
*260  $c1831
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: an evocation of medieval life under 
the reign of Louis XI.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church, Nicholas I
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1834 Italy-Rome: "Notre 
Dame de Paris" placed on the Index. 1850 Russia: All works banned by 
Nicholas I.

9800690
*041  $afre
*10010$aHugo, Victor Marie (1802-1885)
*24510$aNapoleon le Petit
*260  $c1851
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Satire, and indictment of the "Little 
Napoleon" (Napoleon III) as opposed to the "great" (Napoleon I).
*506  $bCensoring body: The Inspector General of Theaters, Napoleon 
III, The Church, Nicholas I, the French Police
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1850 Russia: All works 
banned by Nicholas I. 1853 France: Copies of "Napoleon le Petit" were 
seized by the police. 1853 France: "Napoleon le Petit" was written one 
year after Hugo had been banished by Napoleon III and began his 20 year 
exile for criticizing the government.

*041  $afre
*10010$aHugo, Victor Marie (1802-1885)
*24510$aLes Miserables
*260  $c1862
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: The story centers around the convict 
Jean Valjean, a victim of society who has been imprisoned for 19 years 
for stealing a loaf of bread.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Church, Nicholas I
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1850 Russia: All works 
banned by Nicholas I. 1864 Italy-Rome: "Les Miserables", published two 
years earlier, was listed on the Index. Removed from the Index in 1959.
*518  $a1850
*518  $a1864-1959
*651  $a8023
*651  $a8052
*651  $a8064
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800692
*041  $ager
*10010$aMarx, Karl (1818-1883)
*24510$aRheinische Zeitung
$bNeue Rheinische Zeitung
*260  $c1842
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: A journal of advanced political and 
social ideas. On October 15, 1842 Marx became the editor in Cologne. 
"Rheinische Zeitung" was the liberal democratic organ of a group of 
young merchants, bankers and industrialists.
*506  $bCensoring body: Germany-Cologne authorities, Prussian 
Government, the Boston Post
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1843 Germany-Cologne: 
"Rheinische Zeitung", a journal was suppressed one year after Marx 
became editor. 1843 Germany-Cologne: after the suppression of 
"Rheinische Zeitung", Marx was exiled in Paris and Brussels, but 
returned at the outbreak of revolution in 1848. 1849 Prussia: "Neue 
Rheinische Zeitung" published, "an organ of democracy", which advocated 
nonpayment of taxes, and armed resistance against Emperor Frederick 
William. Publication of the "Neue Rheinische Zeitung" was suspended, 
and the editor, Marx was tried for treason. Although unanimously 
acquitted by a middle-class jury, he was expelled from the country. 
1849 Prussia: After being expelled from Prussia, and being unwelcomed 
in Paris, he made London his home for the rest of his life. 1950-1953 
United States: Marx's works, along with Communist writings generally, 
were heavily criticized in the United States. The Boston Public 
Library, under attack by the Boston Post for including Communist work 
in its collections, put the issue to a vote of its trustees, who upheld 
the inclusion of such works by a 3-2 vote.
*518  $a1843-1953
$3Journal
*651  $a8025
*651  $a6357
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800693
*041  $aeng
*10010$aMarx, Karl (1818-1883)
*24510$aManifesto of the Communist Party
*260  $c1847
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: In June 1847 a secret society, The 
League of the Just, composed mainly of emigrant German handicraftsmen, 
met in London and decided to formulate a political program. They asked 
Marx to join the League. Marx finally overcame his doubts and, with 
Engels joined the organization, which thereupon changed its name to the 
Communist League and enacted a democratic constitution, the "Manifesto 
of the Communist Party".
*506  $bCensoring body: Prussian Government, the Boston Post, Chinese 
Nationalist Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1929 China : The 
Nationalist government sent armies against the sporadic Communist 
outbreaks in the provinces, and stopped, where possible, the reading of 
the "Manifesto of the Communist Party" and "Das Kapital." 1849 Prussia: 
After being expelled from Prussia, and being unwelcomed in Paris, he 
made London his home for the rest of his life. 1878 Germany: Following 
two attempts on the life of William I, Bismarck persuaded the Reichstag 
to enact stringent measures against the Social Democrats, and 
prohibited their literature, including the "Manifesto of the Communist 
Party". 1950-1953 United States: Marx's works, along with Communist 
writings generally, were heavily criticized in the United States. The 
Boston Public Library, under attack by the Boston Post for including 
Communist work in its collections, put the issue to a vote of its 
trustees, who upheld the inclusion of such works by a 3-2 vote.
*518  $a1847-1953
$3Political program
*651  $a6357
*651  $a8025
*651  $a7117
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800694
*041  $ager
*10010$aMarx, Karl (1818-1883)
*24510$aDas Kapital
*260  $c1867-1895
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: The "Bible of the working class" as it 
was officially described in a resolution of the International Working 
Men Association.
*506  $bCensoring body: the Boston Post, Chinese Nationalist Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1929 China : The 
Nationalist government sent armies against the sporadic Communist 
outbreaks in the provinces, and stopped, where possible, the reading of 
the "Manifesto of the Communist Party" and "Das Kapital." 1849 Prussia: 
After being expelled from Prussia, and being unwelcomed in Paris, he 
made London his home for the rest of his life. 1950-1953 United States: 
Marx's works, along with Communist writings generally, were heavily 
criticized in the United States. The Boston Public Library, under 
attack by the Boston Post for including Communist work in its 
collections, put the issue to a vote of its trustees, who upheld the 
inclusion of such works by a 3-2 vote.
*518  $a1929
*518  $a1950-1953
*651  $a6357
*651  $a8025
*651  $a7117
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800695
*041  $ager
*10010$aMarx, Karl (1818-1883)
*24510$aVorwarts
*260  $cc. 1854
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Prussian Foreign Office
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: c.1845 France: Marx was 
expelled at the insistence of the Prussian Foreign Office for 
contributing to the radical magazine "Vorwarts", which was then 
liquidated.
*518  $ac. 1854
$3radical magazine
*651  $a8023
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800696
*041  $afre
*10010$aBaudelaire, Charles Pierre
*24510$aLes Fleurs du Mal
$bEnglish: The Flowers of Evil
*260  $c1909
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Collection of poems, consisting 
largely of poems of decadence, eroticism and spiritual revolution. 
Further editions of the collection prepared by Baudelaire were 
published in 1861 and posthumously in 1866. Each were greatly enlarged 
but omitted the banned poems. These were published however in 1866 in 
Belgium in a collection entitled "Les Epaves" ("The Waifs"). In France 
the ban of the six poems was not lifted until 1949.
*506  $bCensoring body: The government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The author, publisher and 
printer were prosecuted under the Second Empire for an "outrage aux 
bonnes moeurs" (outrage to public decency). Baudelaire was arrested and 
fined 300 francs. In 1866, in Brussels, Belgium, six poems suppressed 
from Les Fleurs du Mal were published under the title of Les Epaves, 
and were widely circulated in France. In 1949, the ban was lifted in 
France.
*518  $a1857-1949
*651  $a8023
*691  $aReligious
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^
9800697
*041  $aeng
$hnor
*10010$aIbsen, Henrik
*24510$aThe Ghosts
*260  $c1890
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Drama, one of the most important of 
the author's realistic period.
*506  $bCensoring body: Norwegian authorities, Lord Chamberlain - 
England, Franco - Spain, Soviet authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1881, Norway, the play was 
intended as a reform and was received with ill will. 1892, England, the 
application for a licence was refused by the Lord Chamberlain. Long 
after Ibsen's position had been recognized in modern letters, the 
censor still interposed his shocked and obstinate personality between 
the British public and the Norwegian author. 1915, England, ban removed 
by the Lord Chamberlain. 1939, Spain, Work purged by the Franco 
Government. 1958, Soviet Union, works formerly banned reported to be 
extremely popular.
*518  $a1891, 1892
*518  $a1939
*651  $a8050
*651  $a8040
*651  $a8051
*651  $a8045
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800698
*041  $agre
*10010$aAristophane (c.448-c.380 B.C.)
*24510$aLysistrata
*260  $c411 B.C.
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Plutarch; United States customs; Nazi 
occupation authorities; Greek military
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: A.D. 66 His comedies were 
considered obscene by Plutarch. 1930 United States: Customs ban lifted 
on "Lysistrata". During the period of prohibition the book was 
published and sold for as little as thirty-five cents; and the drama 
was played in New York and Philadelphia as adapted by Gilbert Seldes. 
1942 Greece-Athens: performance of classic Greek plays banned by Nazi 
occupation authorities. 1954 United States: Post Office officials 
seized a copy of the 1926 translation of "Lysistrata", by Jack Lindsay, 
addressed by Fanfrolico Press, England, to Harry A. Levinson, Beverly 
Hills bookseller. The Post Office quickly reversed itself and delivered 
the book, but only because it was "not for general distribution". 1967 
Greece-Athens: The military clique then ruling the country banned a 
number of classic plays, including those named above, presumably 
because of their independent and antiwar themes. 1955 United States: 
In a successful challenge of the Comstock Act of 1873 which empowered 
the Postmaster General to rule on obscenity of literature sent through 
the mail, "Lysistrata" was declared mailable.
*518  $a0066 A.D.
*518  $a1942-1967
*651  $a6357
*651  $a8027
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800699
*10010$aRabelais, Francois (1494-1553)
*24510$aGargentua
*260  $c1535
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and New York Public Library, New York City
*506  $bCensoring body: New York Society for the Suppression of Vice
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "Founder of the New York 
Society for the Suppression of Vice (1872), whose slogans were: "Morals 
not Art and Literature!" and "Books are feeders for brothels!" Comstock 
campaigned tirelessly for censorship laws not only to stamp out erotic 
subject matter in art or literature, but to suppress information about 
sexuality, reproduction, and birth control. In 1873 he persuaded 
Congress (after less than an hour of debate) to pass the law (Federal 
Anti-Obscenity Act) that banned the mailing of materials found to be 
"lewd", "indecent", "filthy", or "obscene." Over the next forty years 
Comstock prosecuted 3,500 individuals (although no more than 10% were 
found guilty) and had destroyed 120 tons of literature. Books banned 
from the U. S. mails under the Comstock Law included many of the 
greatest classics: Aristophanes Lysistrata, Rabelais's Gargantua, 
Chaucer's Canterbury tales, Boccaccio's Decameron and even The Arabian 
Nights. Furthermore, several modern authors were censored under the 
Comstock Law, amongst them: Honore de Balzac, Victor Hugo, Oscar Wilde, 
Ernst Hemingway, John Dos Passos, Eugene O' Neil, James Joyce, D.H. 
Lawrence, Clifford Odets Erskine Caldwell, John Steinbeck, William 
Faulkner, F. Scott Fitzgerald." (Source: "Sex, Sin and Blasphemy" by 
Marjorie Heins, pg. 19.) Results of incident: "..The Comstock Law 
remains on the books today, although the ban on information about birth 
control has been eliminated. In 1896 the court ruled that the federal 
Comstock Law didn't cover vulgar insults." (Source: "Sex, Sin and 
Blasphemy" by Marjorie Heins, pg. 19.)
*518  $a1873-
*651  $a6357
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^

*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and New York Public Library, New York City
*506  $bCensoring body: New York Society for the Suppression of Vice

Anti-Obscenity Act) that banned the mailing of materials found to be 
"lewd", "indecent", "filthy", or "obscene." Over the next forty years 
Comstock prosecuted 3,500 individuals (although no more than 10% were 
found guilty) and had destroyed 120 tons of literature. Books banned 
from the U. S. mails under the Comstock Law included many of the 
greatest classics: Aristophanes Lysistrata, Rabelais's Gargantua, 
Chaucer's Canterbury tales, Boccaccio's Decameron and even The Arabian 
Nights. Furthermore, several modern authors were censored under the 
Comstock Law, amongst them: Honore de Balzac, Victor Hugo, Oscar Wilde, 
Ernst Hemingway, John Dos Passos, Eugene O' Neil, James Joyce, D.H. 
Lawrence, Clifford Odets Erskine Caldwell, John Steinbeck, William 
Faulkner, F. Scott Fitzgerald." (Source: "Sex, Sin and Blasphemy" by 
Marjorie Heins, pg. 19.) Results of incident: "..The Comstock Law 
remains on the books today, although the ban on information about birth 
control has been eliminated. In 1896 the court ruled that the federal 
Comstock Law didn't cover vulgar insults." (Source: "Sex, Sin and 
Blasphemy" by Marjorie Heins, pg. 19.)
*518  $a1873-
*651  $a6357
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^

*10010$aPassos, John Dos
*24510$a[Works by the author]
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and New York Public Library, New York City
*506  $bCensoring body: New York Society for the Suppression of Vice
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "Founder of the New York 
Society for the Suppression of Vice (1872), whose slogans were: "Morals 
not Art and Literature!" and "Books are feeders for brothels!" Comstock 
campaigned tirelessly for censorship laws not only to stamp out erotic 
subject matter in art or literature, but to suppress information about 
sexuality, reproduction, and birth control. In 1873 he persuaded 
Congress (after less than an hour of debate) to pass the law (Federal 
Anti-Obscenity Act) that banned the mailing of materials found to be 
"lewd", "indecent", "filthy", or "obscene." Over the next forty years 
Comstock prosecuted 3,500 individuals (although no more than 10% were 
found guilty) and had destroyed 120 tons of literature. Books banned 
from the U. S. mails under the Comstock Law included many of the 
greatest classics: Aristophanes Lysistrata, Rabelais's Gargantua, 
Chaucer's Canterbury tales, Boccaccio's Decameron and even The Arabian 
Nights. Furthermore, several modern authors were censored under the 
Comstock Law, amongst them: Honore de Balzac, Victor Hugo, Oscar Wilde, 
Ernst Hemingway, John Dos Passos, Eugene O' Neil, James Joyce, D.H. 
Lawrence, Clifford Odets Erskine Caldwell, John Steinbeck, William 
Faulkner, F. Scott Fitzgerald." (Source: "Sex, Sin and Blasphemy" by 
Marjorie Heins, pg. 19.) Results of incident: "..The Comstock Law 
remains on the books today, although the ban on information about birth 
control has been eliminated. In 1896 the court ruled that the federal 
Comstock Law didn't cover vulgar insults." (Source: "Sex, Sin and 
Blasphemy" by Marjorie Heins, pg. 19.)

9800715
*041  $aeng
*10010$aHawthorne, Nathaniel (1804-1864)
*24510$aThe Scarlet Letter
$b; a Romance
*260  $c1850
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: A novel, dwelling on the tragic 
consequences of unconfessed guilt. This novel was the first U.S. work 
to rank among "classics of world literature."
*506  $bCensoring body: Nicholas I
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1852, Russia: Banned by 
Nicholas I in the "censorship terror."
*518  $a1852
*651  $a8064
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^
9800716
*10010$aVerdi
*24510$aStiffelio
$b; Opera
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and "Village Voice", USA
*505  $aDescription of the work: An opera entitled Stiffelio about "a 
contemporary Protestant minister in Salzburg whose non-violent beliefs 
are shaken by his wife's infidelity."
*506  $bCensoring body: Italian Church and Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Due to the staunch 
Catholic population of 1850's Italy, and the historical policy which 
prohibited in a church service on stage, Stiffelio was considered 
completely inappropriate and was thus transformed into Aroldo, "with 
the hero a returning English crusader, not a man of peace, but of war, 
the blood of countless infidels staining his sword." Stiffelio (its 
original score) was successfully buried during Verdi's lifetime and its 
existence remained unknown until 1968 when two copyists manuscripts 
were discovered in the Naples library, Biblioteca Di San Pietro a 
Majella.
*518  $a1850-
*651  $a8033
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800717
*041  $aeng
*10010$aLanghorne, Clemens Samuel (Mark Twain) (1835-1910)
*24510$aThe Adventures of Tom Sawyer
*260  $c1876
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Public Libraries - USA, Soviet Customs
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1876 U.S.A.-Brooklyn, 
N.Y.: "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" was excluded from the children's 
room in the Public Library. Also excluded from the Denver Public 
Library. 1905 Brooklyn, N.Y.: The book was excluded from children's 
room of the Public Library as a bad example of ingenuous youth. 1930 
Soviet Union: Books confiscated at the border. 1946: Books had become 
best sellers in Soviet Union.
*518  $a1876-1930
*651  $a6357
*651  $a8050
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^
9800718
*041  $aeng
*10010$aLanghorne, Clemens Samuel (Mark Twain) (1835-1910)
*24510$aThe Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
*260  $c1885
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Public Libraries - USA, Soviet Customs
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1885 USA - Concord, 
Massachusets: In the home town of Henry David Thoreau, "The 
Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" was banned by the Public Library as 
"trash and suitable only for the slums." 1930 Soviet Union: Books 
confiscated at the border. 1946: Books had become best sellers in 
Soviet Union. 1957 United States-New York City: Dropped from list of 
approved books for seniors and junior high schools, partly because of 
objection to frequent use of the term "nigger" and famed character, 
"Nigger Jim." NOTE: Mr. Clemens censored "The Adventures of Huckleberry 
Finn" and deleted the profanity and other strong passages, but left 
some which have at times been criticized, such has: "All kings is 
mostly rapscallions" (Ch.23) and "so the king he blatted along" 
(Ch.25). The London Athenaeum has called it one of the six greatest 
books ever written in America. 1905: Barred from the Brooklyn Library 
Children's Room because "Huck not only itches but scratches, and says 
sweat when he should say perspiration." 1957 USA: Dropped from New York 
City schools list of readings for frequent use of the word nigger. 1969 
USA: Removed from Miami-Dade Junior College required reading list 
because it "creates an emotional block for black students that inhibits 
learning."CHALLENGED AS RACIST IN USA: 1976: Winnetka, Illinois 1981: 
Warrington, Pennsylvania 1981: Davenport, Iowa 1982: Fairfax County, 
Virginia 1982: Houston, Texas 1983: State College, Pennsylvania 1984: 
Springfield, Illinois 1984: Waukegan, Illinois 1986: Lincoln, Nebraska
*518  $a1885-1986
*651  $a8050
*651  $a6357
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^
9800719
*041  $aeng
$hgre
*10010$aHomer (c. 850 B.C.)
*24510$aThe Odyssey
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Epic poem.
*506  $bCensoring body: Plato, Emperor Caligula and the Roman Republic
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 387 B.C. Greece: Plato 
suggested expurgating Homer for immature readers. A.D. 35 Rome: 
Caligula tried to suppress "The Odyssey" because it expressed Greek 
ideals of freedom - dangerous in autocratic Rome.
*518  $a0387 B.C - 0035 A.D.
*651  $a8027
*651  $a8033
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
^
9800720
*041  $agre
*10010$aSocrates (c.470-399 B.C.)
*24510$a[His teachings]
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Socrates is described as having "laid 
the philosophical foundation of Western culture". Socrates wrote 
nothing. Information about his personality and doctrine is found 
chiefly in the dialogues of Plato and the 'Memorabilia' of Xenophon.
*506  $bCensoring body: The Athenian Assembly
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 399 B.C.: Socrates 
accused "firstly, of denying the gods recognized by the State and 
introducing new divinities, and secondly of corrupting the young". 
Found guilty, he was condemned to death. Accounts of the events in 
Xenephon's "Memorabilia" and Plato's "Apology". The western history of 
censorship is said to begin here. Results of incident: Although 
Socrates left no writings, his forthrightness as teacher and 
philosopher exposed him to punishment of the State.
*518  $a0399 B.C.
*651  $a8027
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
9800721
*041  $aeng
*10010$aAristophanes (c.448-c.380 B.C.)
*24510$aThe Clouds
*260  $c423 B.C.
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Comedy, an attack on the "modern' 
education and morals as imported and taught by Sophists.
*506  $bCensoring body: Plutarch; Nazi occupation authorities; Greek 
military
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 423 B.C. Greece-Athens : 
"The Clouds" was a play in which Socrates was pilloried as a typical 
representative of impious and destructive speculations. A.D. 66 His 
comedies were considered obscene by Plutarch. 1942 Greece-Athens : 
performance of classic Greek plays banned by Nazi occupation 
authorities. 1967 Greece-Athens : The military clique then ruling the 
country banned a number of classic plays, presumably because of their 
independent and antiwar themes.
*518  $aA.D. 0066
*518  $a1942; 1967
*651  $a8027
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800722
*041  $aeng
*10010$aAristophanes (c.448-c.380 B.C.)
*24510$aThe Birds
*260  $c414 B.C.
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Comedy of fantasy. Some scholars see 
it as a political satire on the imperialistic dreams that had led the 
Athenians to undertake their ill-starred expedition of 415 B.C. against 
Syracuse Sicily.
*506  $bCensoring body: Plutarch, Nazi occupation authorities; Greek 
military
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: A.D. 66 His comedies were 
considered obscene by Plutarch. 1942 Greece-Athens : performance of 
classic Greek plays banned by Nazi occupation authorities. 1967 
Greece-Athens: The military clique then ruling the country banned a 
number of classic plays, presumably because of their independent and 
antiwar themes.
*518  $aA.D. 0066
*518  $a1942; 1967
*651  $a8027
*651  $a8033
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800723
*041  $aeng
*10010$aWhitman, Walt (1819-1892)
*24510$aLeaves of Grass
*260  $c1855
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Collection of poems. The poems 
addressed the citizens of the United States, urging them to be large 
and generous in spirit, a new race of races nurtured in political 
liberty, possessed of united souls and bodies.
*506  $bCensoring body: Society for Suppression of Vice, the Boston, MA 
District Attorney
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1855 United States: The 
poems shocked America puritanism and English Victorianism, although 
Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote to the New York Times, calling the book "the 
most extraordinary piece of wit and wisdom that America has yet 
contributed." The Library Company of Philadelphia was the only American 
library known to have bought a copy of the publication. 1881 United 
States-Boston MA: The District Attorney, at the urging of agents of the 
Society for Suppression of Vice, threatened criminal prosecution unless 
the volume was expurgated. The book was withdrawn in Boston but 
published in 1882 in Philadelphia. Whittier, in rage of indignation, 
threw his first edition into the fire, although he himself had suffered 
persecution for his abolitionist poems.
*518  $a1855-1882
*651  $a6357
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^
9800724
*041  $aeng
*10010$aVizetelly, Henry (1820-1894)
$ePublisher
*24510$aExtracts Principally from English Classics: Showing that the 
Legal Suppression of M. Zola's Novels Would Logically Involve the 
Bowdlerizing of Some of the Greatest Works in English Literature
*260  $bVizetelly
$c1888
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The National Vigilance Association
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1888 England-London: A 
work compiled by and privately printed for Vizetelly, publisher of 
Flaubert, Goncourt, Gautier, Maupassant, Daudet, Bourget, Zola and 
other translations, and many outstanding writers in English. At the 
Instigation of a powerful "purity" group, the National Vigilance 
Association, founded in 1884, Vizetelly was prosecuted, on the basis of 
selected passages, for publishing five works of Zola, two of 
Maupassant, one of Bourget. Aged 70, and ill, he was convicted and 
jailed for three months. 1894 England-London: Vizetelly died shortly 
after release. It was apparently his espousal of books about the 
depressed classes in society, as much as the "coarse" scenes in some 
books, that caused outrage and led the respectable to rationalize that 
he was a mere exploiter of vulgarity.
*518  $a1888-1894
*651  $a8051
*691  $aPolitical
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aCensored

9800725
*041  $aeng
*10010$aBurton, Sir Richard Francis (1821-1890)
*24510$aFirst Footsteps in East Africa
*260  $c1856
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: One of the greatest British scholars - 
explorer of the 19th century. He was the first European to explore the 
forbidden Muslim city of Harer in Somali land, without being executed. 
He described his adventures in this book. Other writings include 
Journals, Notes, Papers, Translations.
*506  $bCensoring body: The publisher, obscenity law, his widow Lady 
Isabel Burton
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1856 England: The publisher
tore out an appendix, written in Latin, which dealt with sexual customs 
of certain tribes. Partly from his experience, Burton learned the techniques 
of publishing to avoid Victorian censorship. 1883-1890 : Burton was 
the principal translator of several works which, in order to sidestep 
obscenity laws, he issued "privately" and, ostensibly, abroad. Among 
these were : "The Kama Sutra of Vatsayana", 1883 (the classic Hindu sex 
manual); "The Book of the Thousands Nights and a Night", 1883-1888; "The 
Perfumed Garden"; "A Manual of Arabian Erotology", 1886: and other works, 
all of which bore imprints such as: "Printed for the Karma Shastra Society 
for Private Subscribers Only, Benares." 1890: Upon the death of the 
explorer, anthropologist, writer and translator, his widow, Lady Isabel 
Burton, destroyed all his remaining private diaries and most of his 
everyday journals, many private letters and papers, and the notes for a 
revised edition of "The Perfumed Garden", which he referred to as "The 
Second Garden." Many of the writing and reading public condemned her.
*518  $a1856
*651  $a8051
*691  $aMoral
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned

9800726
*041  $afre
*10010$aFlaubert, Gustave (1821-1880)
*24510$aMadame Bovary
*260  $c1857
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Catholic Church, New York Society for the 
Suppression of Vice, U.S. National Organization of Decent Literature
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1857 France-Paris: The 
author was taken to court for "outrage aux bonnes moeurs" as depicted 
in "Madame Bovary." He was acquitted on the ground that the passages 
cited by the prosecution, though reprehensible, were few in number 
compared with the extent of the whole work. His counsel pleaded that in 
depicting vice, the author was only endeavoring to promote virtue. 1864 
Italy-Rome: "Madame Bovary" and "Salammbo" were placed on the Index. 
1954 U.S.A.: "Madame Bovary" was on the blacklist of the National 
Organization of Decent Literature.

9800729
*041  $aeng
$hfre
*10010$aFlaubert, Gustave (1821-1880)
*24510$aNovember
$b(written 1842)
*260  $c1842
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Customs Bureau; the New York Society for the 
Suppression of Vice
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1934 U.S.A.-New York City: 
"November" was seized at customs as obscene but released by literary 
experts of the Customs Bureau. 1935 U.S.A.-New York City: the New York 
Society for the Suppression of Vice attacked "November", but Magistrate 
Jonah J. Goldstein discharged the complaint, saying: "The criterion of 
decency is fixed by time, place and geography and all the elements of a 
changing world. A practice regarded as decent in one period may be 
indecent in another." Three years earlier this book had been on the 
Book-of-the-Month Club's selected list.

9800730
*041  $aeng
$hrus
*10010$aTolstoy, Leo (1828-1910)
*24510$aThe Kreutzer Sonata
*260  $c1889
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Russian State, The U.S. Post Office Department, 
the U.S. Attorney General
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1880 Russia: Various works 
printed in Switzerland, England, and Germany, were forbidden. In his 
early days, the writings of Tolstoy were greatly influenced by the 
philosophy of Rousseau. 1890 United States: The Post Office Department 
barred the mailing of copies of newspapers serializing "The Kreutzer 
Sonata." 1890 United States: the U.S. Attorney General ruled the 
department could do this with respect to any installments containing 
material postal officials considered obscene. Theodore Roosevelt, then 
a state politician, denounced the author as a "sexual moral pervert." 
1926 Soviet Union: Many ethical works were banned or confined to the 
large libraries. 1926 Hungary: All works banned. 1929 Italy: All works 
banned except in expensive editions. 1936 Soviet Union: Works topped 
the sales of books.

9800731
*041  $afre
*10010$aZola, Emile (1840-1902)
*24510$aNana
*260  $c1880
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Novel part of the series of the 
Rougont-Maquart. Story of a courtesan
*506  $bCensoring body: The National Vigilance Association in England, 
The French Army, National Organization of Decent Literature
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1888 England: Vizetelly, 
the publisher, was imprisoned for publishing "La Terre"; even in their 
expurgated editions, Zola's novels outraged the Victorian era. 1898 
France: In 1894 Capt. Alfred Dreyfus was degraded and sentenced to 
Devil's Island for life for allegedly selling military secrets. Firm 
exonerating evidence was found in 1896, but Army circles suppressed it, 
denying a new trial, and causing intense protests. Zola denounced the 
military authorities in an open letter, "J'accuse." 1894 Italy-Rome: 
All Zola's works were placed on the Index. 1898 France: After his open 
letter "J'accuse" Zola was convicted of libeling the Army, fled to 
England, and was amnestied in a few months. Dreyfus was pardoned in 
1899 and exonerated formally in 1906. The case convulsed French 
political life and society. 1953 Ireland: All works banned. 1954 United 
States: "Nana" disapproved by the National Organization of Decent 
Literature.

*651  $a8031

*24510$aLa Terre
*260  $bVizetelly
$c1887
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: One of his most grim and outspoken 
novel on the human condition
*506  $bCensoring body: The National Vigilance Association in England, 
National Organization of Decent Literature, the Catholic Church, Irish 
authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1888 England: Vizetelly, 
the publisher, was imprisoned for publishing "La Terre"; even in their 
expurgated editions, Zola's novels outraged the Victorian era. 1898 
France: In 1894 Capt. Alfred Dreyfus was degraded and sentenced to 
Devil's Island for life for allegedly selling military secrets. Firm 
exonerating evidence was found in 1896, but Army circles suppressed it, 
denying a new trial, and causing intense protests. Zola denounced the 
military authorities in an open letter, "J'accuse." 1894 Italy-Rome: 
All Zola's works were placed on the Index. 1898 France: After his open 
letter "J'accuse" Zola was convicted of libeling the Army, fled to 
England, and was amnestied in a few months. Dreyfus was pardoned in 
1899 and exonerated formally in 1906. The case convulsed French 
political life and society. 1953 Ireland: All works banned.

9800733
*041  $afre
*10010$aZola, Emile (1840-1902)
*24510$aJ'accuse
*260  $c1898
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Zola published concerning the Dreyfus 
affair-that of a Jewish French army officer whose trial for treason 
began a 12 year controversy that deeply marked the political and social 
history of the period - a fierce denunciation of the French general 
staff in the newspaper L'Aurore. It took the form of an open letter 
defending the innocence of Dreyfus.
*506  $bCensoring body: The National Vigilance Association in England, 
The French Army, National Organization of Decent Literature, Catholic 
Church, Irish authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1898 France: In 1894 Capt. 
Alfred Dreyfus was degraded and sentenced to Devil's Island for life 
for allegedly selling military secrets. Firm exonerating evidence was 
found in 1896, but Army circles suppressed it, denying a new trial, and 
causing intense protests. Zola denounced the military authorities in an 
open letter, "J'accuse." 1894 Italy-Rome: All Zola's works were placed 
on the Index. 1898 France: After his open letter "J'accuse" Zola was 
convicted of libeling the Army, fled to England, and was amnestied in a 
few months. Dreyfus was pardoned in 1899 and exonerated formally in 
1906. The case convulsed French political life and society. 1953 
Ireland: All works banned.
*518  $a1898-1953

*10010$aJoyce, James
*24510$aUlysses
*260  $c1918
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and National Association of Artists Organizations
*506  $bCensoring body: U.S. Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: In 1918 chapters published 
in the Little Review, are burned by the U.S. Post Office. In 1930, 
while en route to a potential American publisher, the U.S. Post Office 
once again seizes copies of the novel. In 1933, Federal Judge John 
Woolsey lifts the ban on Ulysses.

*10010$aTrotsky, Leon (Bronstein, Lev Davidovich) (1879-1940)
*24510$aSecond Congress of the Russian Socialist Democratic Worker's 
Party: Report of the Siberian Delegation
*260  $c1903
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*505  $aDescription of the work: Held in Brussels and London in July 
1903. Trotsky sided with Menshevick faction - advocating a democratic 
approach to Socialism - against the Bolsheviks rejecting Lenin's 
dictatorial methods and organizational concepts, aiming at immediate 
revolution
*506  $bCensoring body: Russian Imperial Government; Soviet Union 
Government; Italian authorities; German Authorities
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1903 Russia: Banned by the 
Imperial Government. 1927 Soviet Union: Banned by the government. 
Therefore the same writings were banned by two opposing ideologies for 
the same reason - that they opposed the existing philosophies of 
government. 1930 United States-Boston MA: Works banned. 1933 Germany: 
All works banned. 1933 Soviet Union: All works banned 1934 Italy: All 
works banned except in deluxe editions.

$b; play
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and "The Censor Marches On", pg. 68
*506  $bCensoring body: Mayor of Boston, USA
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: In 1929 Mayor Nichols 
prohibited the production of Eugene O'Neill's "Strange Interlude". 
Instead of opposing the demand, the Theater Guild moved the production 
to a suburb beyond the jurisdiction of the city authorities; thousands 
flocked to see the performance.

*24510$aThe Sex Side of Life

9800744
*041  $aeng
*10010$aHall, Radclyffe
*24510$aThe Well of Loneliness
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and The Encyclopedia of Censorship, J.Green, Facts on File 
pg. 3-4
*506  $bCensoring body: British state; New York Court - USA
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The book was found obscene 
in Britain even though it had no explicit descriptions of sex. Expert 
testimony on its literary worth, offered in the English trial by 
Virginia Woolf and other major writers of the day, was rejected by the 
court as irrelevant. A New York Court in 1929, ruled the book obscene 
even though the judge acknowledged that the book was "a well written, 
carefully constructed piece of fiction" with "no unclean words". It was 
penalized because it drew a sympathetic portrait of homosexuality, and 
"pleads for tolerance on the part of society." The prosecutor in the 
case used the Hicklin Rule to demonstrate that some passages were 
obscene and therefore under the Hicklin Rule the entire work was 
obscene. The Hicklin Rule was overturned in 1934 in the case United 
States vs. One Book Entitled Ulysses.
*518  $a1929
*651  $a8051
*651  $a6357
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^
9800745
*041  $aeng
$hara
*10010$aVarious
*24510$aThe Thousand and One Nights
$bOrigin unknown, first translation from the Arabic by A. Galland
*260  $aParis
$c1704-1712
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: U.S. Customs
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1927, New York City, USA: 
The Customs held up 500 sets of the translation by French scholar, 
Mardrus, which were imported from England. 1931 New York City, USA: Ban 
lifted on the unexpurgated translation (1885-1888), by Richard Francis 
Burton, but the prohibition was maintained on the Mardrus edition.
*518  $a1927
*651  $a6357

*70010$aGalland, A.
$etranslator

9800746
*041  $aspa
*10010$aLorca, Federico Garcia
*24510$aThus Five Years Pass
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship and New York Times, October 19, 1980
*506  $bCensoring body: Spanish government under Francisco Franco, 
assassination ordered by Ramon Ruiz Alonso
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "August 9, 1936, Falangist 
soldiers dragged the Spanish poet and playwright Federico Garcia Lorca 
into a field, shot him and tossed his body into an unmarked grave... 
Franco's government tried to obliterate Lorca's memory. His books were 
prohibited, his name forbidden. "One of the first and most famous 
casualties of the Spanish Civil War, Lorca quickly became an almost 
mythical figure, a symbol of all the victims of political oppression 
and fascist tyranny." People began speaking publicly about Lorca again 
in the late 1940's, and The House of Barnardo Alba was the first of his 
plays to be produced in Spain (1950), since his death and since the end 
of the war. Though foreign influence helped to loosen the Franco 
regimes control over Lorca's work, bans were still placed as late as 
1971. Due to public outcry however, Lorca's work was produced. His 
entire body of work remained censored until Franco's death in 1975. 
This did not, however, prevent him from becoming one of the most widely 
read writers in the world.
*518  $a1936-1975
*651  $a8045
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^

1971. Due to public outcry however, Lorca's work was produced. His 
entire body of work remained censored until Franco's death in 1975. 
This did not, however, prevent him from becoming one of the most widely 
read writers in the world.

*10010$aDodgson, Charles L. (Lewis Carroll) (1832-1898)
*24510$aAlice's Adventures in Wonderland
*260  $c1865
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Chinese Governor of Hunan Province
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1931 China: Banned by the 
Governor of Hunan Province on the ground that "Animals should not use 
human language, and that it was disastrous to put animals and human 
beings on the same level."

9800752
*041  $aeng
*10010$aHemingway, Ernest (1898-1961)
*24510$aThe Sun Also Rises
*260  $c1926
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: The Nazis; Irish state, American libraries and 
schools
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1930 Boston MA: "The Sun 
Also Rises" was banned. 1933 Germany: Works burned in the Nazi 
bonfires. 1953 Ireland: "The Sun also Rises" and "Across the River and 
into the Trees" were banned. 1960 United States-California: "The Sun 
Also Rises" banned from San Jose schools. All Hemingway's books 
withdrawn from Riverside school libraries. 1962 United States: "Texans 
for America" opposed textbooks which referred students to books by 
Hemingway.
*518  $a1930-1962
*651  $a8031

9800753
*041  $aeng
*10010$aHemingway, Ernest (1898-1961)
*24510$aA Farewell to Arms
*260  $c1929
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Italian State; Prosecutor of Wayne County and 
the Catholic organizations; Texans for America; The Nazis; Irish state
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1929 Italy: "A Farewell to 
Arms" was banned because of its painfully accurate account of the 
Italian retreat from Caporetto. 1929 United States-Boston, MA: Five 
issues of Scriber's Magazine were prohibited because they contained the 
story of "A Farewell to Arms" . Robert Herrick attacked "A Farewell to 
Arms" in an article entitled "What Is Dirt?" in the November issue of 
Bookman. 1933 Germany: Works burned in the Nazi bonfires. 1939 Ireland: 
"A Farewell to Arms" banned. 1929 United States: The screen version of 
"A Farewell to Arms" was privately censored through Italian influence. 
1954 Sweden-Stockholm: Awarded Nobel prize for literature for "The Old 
Man and the Sea." 1960 United States-California: All Hemingway's books 
withdrawn from Riverside school libraries. 1962 United States: "Texans 
for America" opposed textbooks which referred students to books by Hemingway.

*10010$aHemingway, Ernest (1898-1961)
*24510$aTo Have Not
*260  $c1929
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Prosecutor of Wayne County and the Catholic 
organizations; Texans for America; The Nazis
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1933 Germany: Works burned 
in the Nazi bonfires. 1938 United States-Detroit, MI: "To Have and Have 
Not" was removed from public sale and from circulation in the public 
library, but preserved among works by "writers of standing." It was 
also barred from sale by the Prosecutor of Wayne County on complaint of 
Catholic organizations. 1938 United States-Detroit, MI.: "To Have and 
Have Not "was reported by the American Civil Liberties Union as the 
only book suppressed during the year. In New York distribution was 
forbidden in the Borough of Queens. 1960 United States-California: All 
Hemingway's books withdrawn from Riverside school libraries. 1962 United 
States: "Texans for America" opposed textbooks which referred students 
to books by Hemingway.

*10010$aHemingway, Ernest (1898-1961)
*24510$aFor Whom the Bells Tolls
*260  $c1940
*500  $aSource: Banned Books 387 B.C. to 1978 A.D., by Anne Lyon 
Haight, and Chandler B. Grannis, R.R. Bowker Co, 1978 and The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship. 
*506  $bCensoring body: US libraries and schools
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1941 United States-New 
York, NY: When the Pulitzer Prize Advisory Board recommended "For Whom 
the Bells Tolls" for the 1940 prize, Columbia University President 
Nicholas Murray Butler said "I hope that you will reconsider before you 
ask the University to be associated with an award for work of this 
nature." 1940 United States-New York, N.Y.: There was no Pulitzer price 
for fiction for 1940. The Post Office in the same year declared the 
book nonmailable. 1960 United States-California: "The Sun Also Rises" 
banned from San Jose schools. All Hemingway's book withdrawn from 
Riverside school libraries. 1962 United States: "Texans for America" 
opposed textbooks which referred students to books by Hemingway.

"The Sun Also Rises" banned from San Jose schools. All Hemingway's book

Hemingway.

9800759
*041  $aeng
*10010$aLawrence, D.H.
*24510$aLady Chatterly's Lover
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / New York Public Library, New York City
*506  $bCensoring body: Postmaster General Arthur Summerfield
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The work is deemed "an 
obscene and filthy work" that cannot be sent through the mail by 
Postmaster General Arthur Summerfield. The ban, lifted after two lower 
courts disagreed with Summerfield, is not reinstated by the Supreme 
Court in 1960. The novel went on to sell two million copies in a year.

9800760
*041  $aeng
*10010$aVonnegut, Kurt
*24510$aSlaughterhouse Five
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / New York Public Library, New York City
*506  $bCensoring body: Drake Board of Education
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Bruce Severy, an English 
teacher at Drake High School in North Dakota ordered the book for one 
of his classes. "On 7 November (1973), Mrs. Sheldon Summers, school 
custodian, burned 32 copies of the book because the board members had 
decided that it was pornographic."(Modern Fiction Studies, Kurt 
Vonnegut on Censorship and Moral Values, Vol. 26. Iss. 4. 1981, pg. 
683) The Board of Education did not reconsider its actions.

*24510$aOne Magazine
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / National Association of Artists Organizations
*505  $aDescription of the work: a periodical dedicated to gay life.
*506  $bCensoring body: U.S. Post Office and the Los Angeles Circuit 
Court
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The U.S. Post Office and 
the Los Angeles Circuit Court rule that the magazine can not be sent 
through the mails. In 1959 the Supreme Court rules that One Magazine 
does in fact have the legal right to go through the mail.

9800766
*041  $adut
*24510$aPropria Cures
*250  $a5 March
*260  $c1966
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / "Wat Niet Mocht", Wim Hazen, Uitgeverg de Harmonie, 
Amsterdam, 1982
*505  $aDescription of the work: "Propria Cures" was the student weekly 
publication of the University of Amsterdam. The censored issue was from 
5 March 1966.
*506  $bCensoring body: Publisher
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The front page of this 
issue of "Propria Cures" included a comic by Opland in which a German 
soldier says, "Schweinhunde." Also on the cover was a photograph of 
Queen Wilhelmina, under which was the text "Sla de mot op de kop" 
freely translated as "Hit the Kraut in the face." This is a quotation 
of Queen Wilhelmina. The entire print run of this issue was kept out of 
the bookshops by the publisher.
*518  $aMarch 1966
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8038
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800767
*041  $afre
*24510$aJeune Afrique
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / A Fund For Free Expression Report, Off Censorship and 
Corruption
*505  $aDescription of the work: Algerian press
*506  $bCensoring body: Algerian Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "..the Paris-based Jeune 
Afrique was banned, and the French daily Le Monde was periodically 
seized for carrying articles the government found objectionable." -"Off 
Limits Censorship and Corruption," A Fund for Free Expression Report, 
pg. 8. "...Before the October 1988 riots, it was impossible for 
journalists to investigate or publish material relating to high-level 
government corruption, unless the information was provided by the Chadi 
administration itself. Radio and television were government- run, and 
the print media was published either by the government or the FLN. The 
authorities also tightly controlled the circulation of foreign 
journals...-" "Off Limits Censorship and Corruption," A Fund For Free 
Expression Report, pg. 8
*518  $a1982-1988

*692  $aBanned

*24510$aLe Monde
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / A Fund For Free Expression Report, Off Censorship and

*505  $aDescription of the work: French daily
*506  $bCensoring body: Algerian Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "..the Paris-based Jeune 
Afrique was banned, and the French daily Le Monde was periodically 
seized for carrying articles the government found objectionable." -"Off 
Limits Censorship and Corruption," A Fund for Free Expression Report, 
pg. 8. "...Before the October 1988 riots, it was impossible for 
journalists to investigate or publish material relating to high-level 
government corruption, unless the information was provided by the Chadi 
administration itself. Radio and television were government-run, and 
the print media was published either by the government or the FLN. The 
authorities also tightly controlled the circulation of foreign 
journals...-" "Off Limits Censorship and Corruption," A Fund For Free 
Expression Report, pg. 8

*041  $aeng
$hind
*10010$aToer, Pramoedya Ananta
*24510$aThis Earth of Mankind
*260  $aIndonesia, Jakarta
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Tom Krausse, "Indonesia's Banned Bestseller", World 
Press Review, August 1982, pg. 59
*505  $aDescription of the work: The novel, This Earth of Mankind, was 
orally composed by Pramoedya Ananta Toer while he was a political 
prisoner on Buru Island in eastern Indonesia. The novel tells the story 
of a young Javanese writer's struggle against Dutch Colonial oppression 
in the 1890's.
*506  $bCensoring body: Indonesian Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "Max Lane was sent home 
from his Australian diplomatic post for translating what has been 
described as the best, most beautiful novel in the history of modern 
Indonesian literature. He was recalled from Jakarta last September for 
translating what was the bestselling novel of its time until banned by 
the Indonesian Government..." (Tom Krausse, "Indonesia's Banned 
Bestseller", World Press Review, August 1982, pg. 59) Joesoef Isak, one 
of the publishers of This Earth of Mankind , was jailed in October of 
1981 and following his release was forced to report three times a week 
to the local military. Pramoedya Ananta Toer was imprisoned for the 
publication and later released, and also reports weekly to the 
military. Max Lane was recalled from Jakarta and began working full 
time on translating the works of Pramoedya Ananta Toer.
*518  $aSeptember, 1981
*651  $a7526
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
*70010$aLane, Max
*70010$etranslator
^
9800770
*041  $aeng
$hind
*24510$aWhite Book
*260  $aIndonesia
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / A Fund for Free Expression Report, "Off Limits and 
Corruption", July 1991, pg. 34
*505  $aDescription of the work: "... Students published a "White Book" 
accusing the ruling elite of promoting a culture of corruption by 
example, argued that Suharto was not a suitable candidate for 
re-election as president.. "
*506  $bCensoring body: Suharto Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: " ... In response, Suharto 
sent troops, helicopters and armored cars to university campuses. The 
authorities arrested more than 200 student leaders, convicted them at 
show-trials, and banned seven papers for covering the students' 
protest. The country's most influential journals, including Kompas and 
Sinar Harapan, were among those banned. The government justified the 
bannings by asserting that the media had "shaped tension" in society by 
providing full coverage of the demonstrations... " "... Suharto let the 
newspapers resume publication only after they had signed a statement 
pledging to recognize their responsibility in preventing any 
disturbances to dynamic national stability" and promising not to 
"engage in slanders or other forms of insult directed toward the 
national leadership and members of his family..."

*651  $a7526
