9800771
*041  $aspa
*10010$aWallace, Melvin
$eeditor
*24510$aEl Pueblo
*260  $aNicaragua
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Organization of American States, Inter-American 
Commission of Human Rights
*505  $aDescription of the work: "El Pueblo" was a Maoist newspaper in 
Nicaragua, known to urge its readers to sabotage the state economy
*506  $bCensoring body: members of the Sandinista Popular Army
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The newspaper was 
described as counter-revolutionary by the Nicaraguan authorities and 
closed-down by members of the Sandinista Popular Army. They seized the 
machinery, materials, and office equipment and arrested two journalists 
and their assistant. The newspaper never reopened. As of June 1981 all 
those arrested had been released.
*518  $aJanuary 25, 1980
$3newspaper
*651  $a6245
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aClosed
*70010$aCuadra, Carlos Domingo
*70010$eSr. Writer
^
9800772
*041  $aspa
*24510$aLa Prensa
*260  $aNicaragua
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Organization of American States, Inter-American 
Commission of Human Rights
*505  $aDescription of the work: At the end of September 1980 
there were strikes, unrest and demonstrations against the government in 
the Atlantic region of Bluefields, Nicaragua. The Press and Information 
Chief of the Government Junta told two employees of the newspaper, "La 
Prensa", that they could not report any of the events occurring in 
Bluefields. The employees chose to continue reporting on the incident. 
The Junta then forbade the publication of any of information regarding 
the Bluefields incident.
*506  $bCensoring body: Press and Information Chief of the Government 
Junta
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: As a result, the 
government prohibited "the publication of information on 
counter-revolutionary acts, disorder, attacks on authorities, 
uprisings, strikes, interruption of public services, take-overs of 
land, farms and estates, etc." It is feared that the "etc." gives the 
government too much leeway and may lead to more serious abuses of the 
law in the future. In 1986, "La Prensa" was banned for receiving money 
from the U.S. and for featuring a cover photo of President Ronald 
Reagan giving a victory salute after Congress voted to give
100 million dollars to Contra aid. "La Prensa" has since reopened.
*518  $aOctober 1980
$3newspaper
*651  $a6245
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800773
*041  $aeng
$harab
*10010$aHamid, Alaa
*24510$aThe Void in a Man's Mind
*260  $aEgypt
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Karim Alrawi, New Statesman and Society, 'Egypt's 
Rushdie', 1/31,1992 v. 5, no. 187, Pg. 27
*505  $aDescription of the work: Alaa Hamid's novel "The Void in a 
Man's Mind" outraged Egyptian Muslim fundamentalists, primarily through 
the activities of the central character in the novel who "meets with 
various prophets in compromising positions."
*506  $bCensoring body: Islamic Research Center
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "...The decision to ban 
the novel was taken by the Islamic Research centre, a department of 
Al-Azhar, Egypt's Islamic university. Once the religious authorities 
had declared the book "offensive to religion", the state authorities 
were free to take any action they saw fit.." "On December 25, 1981, 
Alaa Hamid was sentenced to eight years in prison on charges of blasphemy 
spurred by his novel. "....Also awarded eight year's each were the book's 
publisher and distributor, Mohammad Madbouli, and the owner of the press 
on which it was printed, Fathi Fadel. Such a judgment is unprecedented 
in modern Egyptian history. For Alaa Hami, who is in very poor health it 
is tantamount to a death sentence...."

*651  $a5325
*691  $aReligious

9800774
*041  $aeng
*10010$aWillhoite, Michael
*24510$aDaddy's Roommate
*260  $aUSA
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Office for Intellectual Freedom, American Library 
Association
*505  $aDescription of the work: children's book about gay parenting
*506  $bCensoring body: Mercer County Library
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Lawrence resident Keith 
Smith complained to the Mercer County Library commission and writing to 
County Executive Rober Prunetti. His complaints eventually prompted the 
library commission to move the book, along with Heather Has Two 
Mommies, by Leslea Newman, out of the children's section and into the 
parenting section. In March, a library system review committtee had 
recommended that the books remain in the children's section. That 
decision was reversed by the commission after Prunetti said he simply 
passed the missive on to the county counsel, who advised the commission 
to review Smith's complaint. The books remain in the parenting section 
of the library.

9800776
*041  $aeng
*10010$aMcDermott, Beverly Brodsky
*24510$aThe Golem: Jewish Legend
*260  $aUSA
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Office for Intellectual Freedom, American Library 
Association
*505  $aDescription of the work: The vividly illustrated book, about 
sixteenth century persecution of Jews in Prague, tells the story of a 
rabbi who makes a monster out of clay to protect Jews in his village 
from gentiles who want to kill them. Expressionistic pictures show the 
monster destroying the mob.
*506  $bCensoring body: Newburgh School officials
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The first-teacher, Phyllis 
Hoyt, asked Newburgh School officials to ban this award-winning 
children's book about the persecution of Jews in sixteenth century 
Prague, and filed a formal request to remove the book from Newburgh 
city school libraries. She said the book contains strong language and 
threatening artwork that children might not understand. The book was 
removed as of November 1993.
*518  $a1 April 1994
*651  $a6357
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aCensored
^
9800777
*041  $aeng
*10010$aDickey, James
*24510$aDeliverance
*260  $aUSA
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Office for Intellectual Freedom, American Library 
Association
*506  $bCensoring body: Parent Cindy Hochstetler and Bismarck School 
Board
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Parent Cindy Hochstetler 
won part of her battle to get "shocking and pornographic" books out of 
Hughes Junior High School classrooms and libraries, and was continuing 
to fight the remainder. In April, Hochstetler filed complaints against 
library books Deliverance, by James Dickey, Vision Quest, by Terry 
Davis, and Sex Education, by Jenny Davis. She also lodged protests 
against seventh-grade classrooms use of Dead Birds Singing, by Marc 
Talbert, and Jason and Marceline, by Jerry Spinelle. In late July 
librarians agreed to move Deliverance and Vision Quest to high school 
libraries. On August 2, a review committee voted unanimously to keep 
Sex Education in the library and 8-1 to keep the Talbert and Spinelle 
books on the seventh grade reading list. Results of incident: The reading 
list remained unchanged along with Sex Education remaining in the library, 
but both Vision Quest and Deliverance were removed.
*518  $a2 August 1993
*651  $a6357
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned

*24510$aTrauko
*250  $aDecember 7
*260  $aChile
$c1989
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Revista Nuevosaires, April 1991, No. 2
*505  $aDescription of the work: "Trauko" is a magazine containing 
nudity and sexually explicit material
*506  $bCensoring body: Chilean government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The magazine was censored 
on December 7, 1989. On March 27, 1990, its publisher was condemned to 
41 days in prison, The prison sentance was changed and the defendant 
was to sign-in monthly at the Patronato Nacional de Reos (National 
Council for Defendants) for one year.

9800781
*041  $aeng
*24510$aHolt, Rinehart and Winston Health Textbook
*260  $aUSA
$bHolt, Rinehart & Winston Publishing
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / New York Times, 3/17/94
*505  $aDescription of the work: Five health textbooks
*506  $bCensoring body: State of Texas, Texas Board of Education
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Holt, Rinehart and Winston 
Inc. said it was pulling its 700-page high school health text out of 
the huge Texas textbook market not only because making scores of 
requested revisions was economically unfeasible but also because 
ethical issues were at stake. The publishers decision came after months 
of Texas Board of Education hearings in which family-planning, 
anti-abortion, gay-advocacy, fundamentalist Christian and other groups 
debated the merits of five health texts, written by Holt and four other 
publishers. The board, which buys all text-books for the state, last 
month requested a total of 400 revisions in the five texts, with the 
largest percentage of them for the Holt book, including the deletion of 
toll-free numbers for gay and lesbian groups and for teenage suicide 
prevention groups. The state wanted to see passages on homosexuality 
abridged, the addition of language describing Texas's sodomy laws and 
the deletion of a number of clinical illustrations, including a 
self-examination for testicular cancer and two comparing circumcised 
and uncircumcised penises. Holt refused to make changes. Texas is one of 22 
states in which government committees must approve all texts sold in 
the state. Because Texas controls such a large market share, publishers 
often develop texts to meet the standards set by its 15-member Board of 
Education and then market them nationwide.
*518  $aMarch 1994
*651  $a6357
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aCensored
^
9800782
*041  $aind
*24510$aMonitor
*260  $aJakarta, Indonesia
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / South-East Asia Correspondent, The Economist, Nov. 17, 
1990, pg. 41
*506  $bCensoring body: Muslims
*506  $eDescription of the work: An article that appeared in the "... 
Monitor, a mass circulation weekly tabloid that has frequently flirted 
with the local limits of good taste. In October of 1990, Mr. Arswendo 
Atmowilto, the paper's editor, published a postcard poll of the 50 most 
admirable public figures. President Suharto, unsuprisingly came first. 
Iraq's Mr. Saddam Hussein managed seventh place, and Mr. Arswendo came 
tenth-one place ahead of the prophet (Muhammed) himself."
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: The results of the poll 
published by the Monitor caused a great deal of controversy with the 
Muslim culture. "... At the end of October a mob of young men ransacked 
the offices of the Monitor... Muslims howled that Mr. Arswendo was even 
worse than Mr. Salman Rushdie, who at least never claimed to be more 
admirable than Muhammed." President Suharto sent troops to quell the 
mob, arrested Mr. Atmowilto and shut down the Monitor. "President 
Suharto said he wanted Mr. Arswendo brought to court."
*518  $aOctober, 1990
*651  $a7526
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aCensored
^
9800783
*041  $achi
*24510$aWorld Economic Herald
*250  $aApril 24
*260  $aChina, Shanghai
$bShanghai's World Economic Herald
$c1987
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Andrew Giarelli, World Press Review, May 1990, pg. 26
*505  $aDescription of the work: "In mid-April, disgraced former party 
chief Hu Yaobang died, and days later the Herald held a forum on Hu, a 
reformer who had been removed from office in 1987. The paper's April 24 
edition covered the forum, with comments by dissident intellectuals 
such as political scientist Yan Jiaqi."
*506  $bCensoring body: Shanghai Authorities; Shanghai party head, 
Jiang Zemin
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Shanghai party head, Jiang 
Zemin, demanded that the editor of the Herald, Qin Benli, remove 
several paragraphs from the April 24 issue. Qin Benli ignored the 
demands and proceeded to order a full press run the following day. 
Zemin responded by confiscating all copies of the issue and on April 26 
removed Qin from his position as editor. A revised issue of the April 
24 publication produced under party supervision replaced the comments 
of the critics with official statements from government authorities, 
and furthermore removed the cover photo of recent student 
demonstrations. "... The Herald printed its May 1 and May 8 issues 
under close supervision by the rectification committee, while the staff 
communicated secretly with Qin. The editions were a mix of censored 
articles and articles that the staff slipped into press runs against 
explicit committee orders. The May 8 edition was the Herald's last; 
shortly thereafter, the paper was suspended from publication... Two 
weeks after the June 4 massacre in Tiananmen Square, Qin was placed 
under house arrest and ordered to discontinue study sessions. The 
Herald was officially closed in March, 1990.
*518  $aApril, 1989
$3Newspaper
*651  $a7117
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
*692  $aClosed
*70010$aBenli, Qin
*70010$aeditor
^
9800784
*041  $aind
*24510$aSinar Harapan
*250  $aOctober
*260  $aIndonesia
$c1986
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / A Fund for Free Expression Report, "Off Limits and 
Corruption", July 1991, pg. 30
*505  $aDescription of the work: An article which appeared in the 
Indonesian newspaper Sinar Harapan, the country's second most 
influential paper, which revealed the governments planned abolition of 
a number of import monopolies.
*506  $bCensoring body: President Suharto
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "... In October 1986, 
Suharto temporarily banned Sinar Harapan, for breaking a story on the 
planned abolition of a number of import monopolies. About two weeks 
after Sinar Harapano's banning, the government announced the abolition 
of 165 import monopolies - but not those controlled by the Suharto 
family, such as steel, plastics and milk. And in a surprise move, 
Suharto family members Bambang and Sudwikatmono made offers to buy the 
paper - an offer that was not pursued apparently because Suharto's 
advisors convinced him that a buyout would hurt his international 
image... " "... Sinar Harapan reappeared in February 1987 as a new 
paper, Suara Pembaruan, but with a different publisher, editor-in chief 
and business manager, and with the strongest Suharto critics no longer 
on the editorial board..."
*518  $aOctober, 1986
*651  $a7526
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800785
*041  $achi
*10010$aLawrence, D.H.
*24510$aLady Chatterly's Lover
*260  $aChina
$bHunan People's Press
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Yi Chin, "Publishing in China in the Post-Mao Era", 
Asian Survey, June 1992, Vol. 32, No. 6 Pg. 568-582
*505  $aDescription of the work: Lady Chatterly's Lover", by D.H. 
Lawrence first translated into Chinese by Rao Shu-yi in 1936.
*506  $bCensoring body: Central Bureau
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: In December of 1986 Hunan 
People's Press challenged Chinese censors with the publication of D.H. 
Lawrence's Lady Chatterly's Lover. After the first printing, Hunan 
Press foresaw huge financial rewards in the venture, and expanded the 
printing to 600,000 copies. Hunan Press managed to distribute 230,000 
copies, which quickly sold out. The popularity of the novel incensed 
the Central Bureau, which ordered the booksellers to stop advertising 
and selling the novel. The books were now open to the movements of the 
Black Market and pirating. The Bureau then targeted the source, Hunan 
Press, and ordered the remaining 130,000 copies to be sealed. The chief 
editor Zhu Zhen lost his position, the president of the Press was given 
a serious warning and Tang Yin-sun (editor of translated foreign 
literature) was asked to retire voluntarily.
*518  $a1987
*651  $a7117
*691  $aMoral
*692  $aBanned
^
9800786
*041  $akor
*10010$aCouncil for Democratic Press Movement
*24510$aMal, Council for Democratic Press Movement
*250  $aSeptember 6
*260  $aRepublic of Korea (South Korea)
$c1986
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Asia Watch, Freedom of Expression in the Republic of 
Korea, August, 1988, Pg. 48-51, vii.
*505  $aDescription of the work: In December 1984, a group of 
journalists who had been dismissed during the government's press purges 
in 1974 and 1980 formed the Council for Democratic Press Movement 
(CDPM). CDPM publishes Mal ("Words"), an unregistered, bimonthly 
periodical.
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of Culture
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "...Until the summer of 
1987, Mal was the target of constant government harassment, including 
police raids of the CDPM offices, confiscation of the organization's 
files, and the frequent detention of its editors on charges of 
"spreading false rumors." As a result, CDPM was forced to distribute 
the periodical covertly. On September 6, 1986 a special 63-page edition 
of Mal was devoted entirely to an expose of the government's daily 
issuance of 'guidelines" to the nation's newspapers. As described in 
Mal, the "information guidelines" (Hongbo Chojong Jichim) are 
instructions to the press, which are sent every day to each newspaper 
publisher by the Department of Public Information Control (DPIC) of the 
Ministry of Culture and Information. Results of incident: "...Thousands 
of copies of that edition of Mal were confiscated and several 
journalists associated with the magazine were arrested. One was 
reportedly tortured. Three of the journalists were convicted, but all 
were released after the trial. It is unclear at the present whether the 
practice of calling editors with advice has continued and, if so, to 
what extent..."
*518  $aSeptember, 1986
*651  $a7121
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
9800787
*041  $aeng
*10010$aRushdie, Salman
*24510$aThe Satanic Verses
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Jagdish Bhatia, "India Bans a Novel of the Sacred and 
Profane", Far Eastern Economic Review, Oct. 27, 1988, Pg. 50-51
*505  $aDescription of the work: Salman Rushdie's novel "The Satanic 
Verses" addresses "... the foundation of Islam, Britain in the Era of 
Thatcherism, the Asian immigrant community and a variety of allied 
concerns..." (Jonathon Green, "The Encyclopedia of Censorship", pg. 
269) The novel contains passages which the Islamic community claimed 
blasphemed Islam and the Koran.
*506  $bCensoring body: Indian Muslim Community
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "... The Home Ministry 
order came in the wake of petitions from a number of representatives of 
the Indian Muslim community, including former union minister Khursheed 
Alam Khan and several members of parliament, requesting the government 
not to allow the book to enter the country because parts of it were 
offensive to Islamic sensibilities. "A government spokesman, stressing 
the ban was 'not intended to cast any aspersion on the literary merit 
of the book,' said the step had been taken from the limited point of 
view of avoiding trouble and communal tension... " "... Most of the 
critics of the novel make no bones about the fact that they have not 
read the book, but only its reviews - largely favourable ones from a 
literary viewpoint. They also have focused their attention on comments 
by the noted author, historian, and columnist Khush want Singh who... 
had vetted the book and deemed that it contained 'several derogatory 
references to the Prophet and the Koran and portrayed Muhammad as a 
small time impostor....'" Results of incident: The novel is still 
banned.
*518  $a1988
*651  $a7425

9800788
*041  $afre
*24510$aLa Nation
*250  $aAugust
*260  $aAlgeria
$c1992
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Eileen Byrne, Index on Censorship, "Dialogue 
Suspended", 2/ 1993, Pgs. 21-23
*506  $bCensoring body: Procurer de la Republique (Attorney General)
*505  $aDescription of the work: "Founded in April 1992, "La Nation" 
has met censorship head on. The official reason for its suspension in 
August (1992), given by the Procurer de la Republique (Attorney 
General), was that it had 'threatened the higher national interest' by 
publishing 'unfounded information concerning the allegedly imminent 
trial of a leading smuggler in Southern Algeria.'"
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "On the morning after the 
assassination of Mohammed Boudiaf (High Committee of State Chair)," La 
Nation's front-page headline read: 'Une suele piste: la mafia 
politico-financiere' (One single trail: the politico-financial mafia'). 
The headline was quoted in international press coverage of Algeria, and 
on a local level triggered the re-entry of the catch-phrase 'mafia' 
into the shorthand of political discussion. Some of La Nation's staff 
made preparations to resume publication following the lifting of the 
ban. But on 19 October (1992), Algier's leading dailies carried a 
statement by five of La Nation's senior editorial staff, including the 
former editor Ammar Belhimer, to the effect that they were not prepared 
to work for La Nation even if it was to overcome funding problems and 
reappear in the streets. Their statement condemned 'direct censorship 
in the form of a lengthy suspension at a crucial stage in the promotion 
and launching of the newspaper and indirect (through depriving it of 
all advertising, which is under monopoly control)." Results of 
incident: "...La Nation was in the process of challenging the legality 
of the Attorney General's charge in the courts, (with two other papers 
which had been suspended) when the ban was lifted on 8 October...."
*518  $aAugust, 1992
*651  $a5311
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSuspended
*692  $aCensored
^
9800789
*041  $aeng
*24510$aTell
*260  $aNigeria
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Africa Report, "To Tell the Truth Is Risky Business in 
Nigeria," Jan/Feb. 1994, Pg. 10-11
*505  $aDescription of the work: After its first year on the 
newsstands, "... Tell gained a reputation as a leader in questioning 
(military ruler Ibrahim) Babangida's willingness to hand over power to 
a civilian government. Tell's popularity soared in the run-up to the 
June 1993 presidential election and in the turbulent aftermath. The 
magazine's print run was as high as 100,000 copies a week at the time, 
according to Igiebor..."
*506  $bCensoring body: State security forces
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "... Tell became one of 
Babangida regime's favorite targets in April after the magazine 
published an interview with former head of state Gen. Olusegun 
Obasanjo. The cover of the issue featured a quote from Obasanjo in 
large block red letters, which read, "IBB's Regime is a Fraud." Over 
the next four months, state security forces kept the magazine's offices 
under constant surveillance, occupied them on more then one occasion, 
seized thousands of copies of the magazine, and assaulted its 
journalists..." This consistent pressure from the government forced 
Tell to begin printing underground in July of 1993. "On August 15, 
state security operatives and police ransacked the magazine's offices 
and detained Igiebor, executive editor Kola Ilori, managing editor 
Onome Osifo-Whiskey, and senior associate editor Ayodele Akinkuoto for 
12 days. Even with the senior editors in detention, the attacks on Tell 
continued. "...When the editors were finally released on August 27, 
Ernst Shonekan was Nigeria's president. The end of the Babangida regime 
was a welcome respite for "Tell." All told, 500,000 copies of the 
magazine had been seized from printers, distributors, and vendors in 
the streets during the last four months of Babangida's rule, according 
to Ilori... In addition, Tell's Ilori pointed out that the magazine 
remained under surveillance by the security forces through Shonekan's 
short reign.
*518  $aApril 1993
*651  $a5548
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSeized

*505  $aDescription of the work: French-language weekly magazine

FIS supporter under the headline 'Islamic Women. Comfortable in Their 
Skin? Uncomfortable in Their Century!' Results of incident: "...On the

permitting access to the paper's journalists. "L'Observateur" is 
suspended indefinitely.

9800791
*041  $ajpn
*10010$aIenaga, Professor Saburo
*24510$aThe New History of Japan
*260  $aJapan
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Karl Taro Greenfield, The Nation, "Erasing History", 
4/19/93, Pg. 508-509
*505  $aDescription of the work: a textbook commissioned for Japanese 
high schools, which included information on Japan's World War II 
atrocities
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of Education
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: "...Ienega's textbook, 
"The New History of Japan", was originally commissioned by the Ministry 
of Education. Upon review of the completed manuscript however, the 
ministry demanded that Ienega delete all sections on wartime 
atrocities. Ienaga refused and filed suit, claiming that the ministry's 
review procedure violated his constitutional right to freedom of 
expression and denied students freedom of education. As the case wended 
its way through Japan's Byzantine court system over the next 
twenty-eight years, the central question evolved from whether it is 
proper to to teach Japanese children about what happened during WWII 
whether the Education Ministry can legally censor textbooks....." 
Results of incident: On March 16, 1992 Japan's Supreme Court ruled to 
uphold the censorship decision, furthermore the court maintained that 
"the government has the right to to decide educational content." Since 
Japanese high-schools all use the same textbooks approved by the 
Ministry of Education, the Supreme Court's ruling insures that the 
"official censored version is the only one students will study in 
school."
*518  $a1965-
*651  $a7130
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
^
9800792
*041  $afre
*10010$aNjawe, Pius
*24510$aLe Messanger
*250  $aDecember 27 #209
*260  $aCameroon
$c1990
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Human Rights Watch/Africa Watch, Cameroon: Attacks 
Against Independent Press, 2/12/91
*505  $aDescription of the work: Human Rights Watch/Africa Watch, 
Cameroon: Attacks Against Independent Press, 2/12/91
*506  $bCensoring body: Cameroon Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: In early January charges 
were brought against Njawe and Monga--Article 153 of the Penal Code, 
showing contempt for the President of the Republic, and Article 154, 
showing contempt for members of the national assembly, the Courts and 
Tribunals--relating to (the) open letter written by Monga to President 
Biya ... On December 27, shortly after #209 of the issue was put on 
sale, police began to confiscate it in the streets. Reports indicate 
that police raided the offices of Le Messager that night; many of the 
employees were interrogated, and some were taken to the police station. 
On January 1, Monga was arrested and interrogated. He was held without 
charge and was not permitted any visitors until his release on January 
3. The passports of both Njawe and Monga were confiscated on January 
7..... ...The first session of Monga and Njawa's trial took place on 
January 10 in Douala. ..On the night of January 22-23, the offices of 
Le Messager were broken into. Among the items taken was the central 
memory of the newspaper's computer system. The circumstances 
surrounding the burglary remain suspicious.
*518  $aDecember 27, 1990
*651  $a5118
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSeized
*70010$aMonga, Celestin

9800793
*041  $aeng
*10010$aSilverstein, Charles
*24510$aJoy of Gay Sex
*260  $aCanada
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / "NOW", May 22, 1986
*506  $bCensoring body: Canadian Customs and Toronto Police
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Two Toronto police 
officers citing a customs ban were able to have the book removed from 
virtually every bookstore in Canada. Glad Day Bookstore in Toronto 
appealed the action. The deputy minister of customs turned down this 
appeal, ruling that the book's depictions and illustrations of anal sex 
make it obscene. At the time, the book did not appear on the monthly 
Canadian customs list of over 3000 titles which were denied entry to 
Canada. Results of incident: More and more magazines sold at Glad Day 
Bookshop are missing whole sections, and any pictures depicting anal 
intercourse have a large black dot covering the offending act. 
Guidelines have been instituted by the federal justice department 
concerning importable materials

9800794
*041  $aeng
*10010$aGoodman, Daniel Carson
*24510$aHagar Revelly
*260  $aUSA
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Submission by Gaitane Verna
*505  $aDescription of the work: A novel written by a social hygienist 
hoping to instruct the young in the dangers of vice.
*506  $bCensoring body: Anthony Comstock
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: 1914 the novel was 
attacked by Anthony Comstock. The publisher was acquitted after a brief 
trial in the Federal court. The importance of this case lay in the opinion 
of Judge Learned Hand, which contained the first serious legal challenge 
to the Hicklin Rule.

9800795
*041  $aeng
*10010$aMapanje, Jack
*24510$aOf Chameleons and Gods
*260  $aMalawi
*500  $aSource: The File Room exhibit: http://www.thefileroom.org/ maintained by the National Coalition Against Censorship / Human Rights Watch/Africa Watch, "Where Silence Rules, 
The Suppression of Dissent in Malawi," October 1990, Pg. 75-79
*506  $bCensoring body: Malawian Government
*506  $eDescription and results of incident: Jack Mapanje was arrested 
by police on September 25, 1987. Since then he has been detained 
without charge--and without any public explanation--at Mikuyu Prison. 
In the absence of any statement from the government the precise reasons 
for his detention are a matter of speculation, although clearly it was 
Mapanje's writing which upset the authorities. His 1981 collection of 
poems, Of Chameleons and Gods, is banned from circulating in schools 
and bookshops in Malawi. After his arrest, Mapanje was first taken in 
handcuffs to the University of Malawi, where he is head of the 
Department of English Language and Literature. The police searched his 
office and seized various manuscripts. When Of Chameleons and Gods was 
published in 1981 it was neither officially proscribed nor cleared for 
sale. Thus bookshops were not allowed to display it, but no one could 
be prosecuted for possessing a copy. In 1985 the Ministry of Education 
and Culture issued a circular banning its use in schools and colleges.
*518  $aSeptember 25, 1987

*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned

*24510$aIs censorship in Israel getting worse?
*260  $aTel Aviv

9801063
*041  $aeng
*24510$a[Media]
*260  $a[Africa]
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/InterPress Third World News Agency /Reporters sans Frontieres
*505  $aIn Uganda, journalists are accused of sedition if they report 
on the war in the north of the country between the army and the two 
principal rebel groups, Army of the Ugandan People and the United 
Christian Democratic Army. In Rwanda, journalists reporting on the 
death squads roaming the country risk being liquidated by these same 
squads. In Togo, the press has been held hostage between the power 
struggle between President Gnassingbe Eyadema and the transitional 
government. Moreover, the frequent forcible entry of Togolese Armed 
Forces (FAT), loyal to Eyadema, into the offices of the national radio 
has become the nation's national sport. In 1992, three journalists were 
killed in Chad.As of January 1993, seven journalists continue to be 
detained (five in Sudan, one in Angola and one in Rwanda).
*506  $bAuthorities
*518  $a29 April 1993
$3Newspaper
*650  $aAngola
*650  $aBurundi
*650  $aCameroon
*650  $aChad
*650  $aKenya
*650  $aRwanda
*650  $aSomalia
*650  $aSudan
*650  $aTogo
*650  $aUganda
*650  $aZaire

9801064
*041  $aeng
*24510$aCrossroads of Ideas; The Citizen
*260  $c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*506  $bMinistry of Communciation
*506  $eOn 22 December 1993, the Ministry of Communciation issued an 
order prohibiting "the publication, distribution, circulation or sale 
on Burundian territory" the private opposition newspaper "Crossroads of 
Ideas". The newspaper was accused of having published on 15 December 
1993 in issue #34 an article entitled "National heroes or Head of Tribe 
of Decapitators" illustrated with a photograph of the grave of former 
President Melchior Ndadaye assassinated on 21 October 1993. The private 
bi-monthly "The Citizen" was a target of harassment during December 
1993.
*518  $aDecember 1993
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5117

*692  $aBanned
*74000$aCrossroads of Ideas

9801065
*041  $afre
*24510$aLe Nouvel Independant. Challenge Hebdo. Le Messager
*260  $aCameroon
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters Sans Frontieres
*505  $a"Le Nouvel Independant", was ordered suspended 31 December 1993 
by order of the deputy prime minister in charge of territorial 
governance. The censorship office of this  ministry had demanded the 
withdrawal of an article on the involvement of the presidency in a 
counterfeiting operation. Despite this order, the magazine continueded 
to publish, leading to the arrest and detention of its director Ndzama 
Seme from 7 to 10 January 1994. Without a search warrant the police 
proceeded to thoroughly search his home, and seized copies of the 14 
editions of the paper which have appeared since July 1993. Issue number 
15 of the newspaper, which was to have appeared on 6 January, was 
seized at the printer's and the paper was served with a suspension 
order by the government. The following day, 8 March, the director of 
"Le Messager", Pius Njawe, was summoned to the offices of the 
provincial division of the judicial police in Douala for "not 
respecting censorship". Another weekly, "Challenge Hebdo", has been 
suspended since mid-February for having published an interview with an 
associate of the president who had served a prison term.
*506  $bPolice and the deputy prime minister
*518  $a7 January 1994
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5118
*691  $aPolitical

*692  $aSuspended

*70010$aNjawe, Pius

*74000$aLe Messager
*74000$aChallenge Hebdo

9801066
*041  $afre
*24510$aLe Messager. Challenge Hebdo. Le Nouvel Independant
*260  $aCameroon
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aThe 7 March 1994 edition of the weekly "Le Messager" was seized 
by the authorities. This edition was devoted to articles on the 
conflict between Cameroon and Nigeria and several of these, in the view 
of the Cameroon authorities, threatened "public order". Several of the 
articles, as well as the editorial, had been rejected by the 
authorities before publication, as publishers must submit their new 
editions to prior censorship before publication

9801067
*041  $afre
*24510$aPerspectives Hebdo
*260  $aCameroon
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aThe independent weekly "Perspectives Hebdo" was suspended by 
order of the Ministry of Territorial Administration on 23 March 1994. 
According to reports, "Perspectives Hebdo" was suspended for not 
conforming to censorship regulations, which require two copies of every 
issue to be deposited with the authorities a few hours before 
publication for purposes of prior censorship. In its 17 March 1994 
edition "Perspectives Hebdo" published an article on the marriage of 
President Paul Biya. This edition was put on sale for a few hours 
before being seized by police. The weekly's publisher, Joseph-Marie 
Besseri, reports that the 17 March edition was submitted to prior 
censorship and approved for sale. "Perspectives Hebdo" is the third 
newspaper to be suspended in 1994. In 1992, several publications were 
suspended for varying lengths of time
*506  $bMinistry of Territorial Administration
*518  $a23 March 1994
$3Weekly newspaper
*651  $a5118
*691  $aPolitical

*692  $aSuspended

98010608
*041  $afre
*24510$aLa Nouvelle Expression. l'Expression. Galaxie. l'Ami du peuple. 
La Vision. Challenge Hebdo. Challenge Nouvelle. Le Quotidien
*260  $aCameroon
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)
*505  $aAt least eight private Douala-based newspapers were ordered 
suspended by the government, allegedly for failing to submit issues to 
a censor, as required by the 1990 Freedom of Social Communication law. 
By the end of the year, they were still suspended. Several of the 
newspapers continued to publish, and many of their vendors were 
detained and beaten.

*505  $aThe English-edition of the Douala-based Le Messager newspaper 
was seized after it published an announcement for a demonstration 
organized by the Cameroon Anglophone Movement
*506  $bAuthorities
*518  $a14 January 1992
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5118
*691  $aPolitical

^
9801071
*041  $afre
*24510$aLe Messager
*260  $aCameroon
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Inter Press Service
*505  $aCameroonian journalist Pius Njawe is not unused to state 
harassment. The paper he edits, Le Messager, was suspended from 
publication on Sep. 4 and raided by police on Oct. 3 last year. On Oct. 
14 his nephew Jean-Pierre Njawe and staff member Simo Emmanuel were 
followed by police and arrested as they returned to the office after 
taking Pius's children to school. They were held overnight and 
ill-treated in an attempt to make them sign statements implicating Pius 
in criminal activities. Pius himself had managed to slip out of the 
country the previous day. The arrested journalists, including Severin 
Tchounkeu, the editor of La Nouvelle Expression, cartoonist Theotsapi 
of Challenge-Hebdo, say they were taken to the hq of the army's 'mobile 
intervention force' and beaten. After his return to Cameroon, Pius was 
arrested again on May 12 this year, along with Germain Koumyo Ekwe, 
editor of the independent weekly L'opinion. They were released the next 
day. According to Article 19, attacks on the press have worsened since 
the October 1992 election in which President Paul Biya was returned to 
power amid allegations of intimidation and ballot rigging.
*506  $bPolice and Cameroonian authorities
$eSection 13 of the Cameroonian law relating to freedom of mass 
communication which was enacted in 1990, states that a publisher shall 
submit to the state council two signed copies of the publication at 
least two hours before distribution. While section 14 requires that a 
publisher shall submit two signed copies or brush proofs to the senior 
divisional officer, an administrative official, at least four hours 
before distribution (or two hours in the case of a daily newspaper). 
Section 14 states that a publication may be censored 'where there is a 
conflict with the principles of public policy.'
*518  $a16 July 1993
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5118
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*74000$aLe Messager
^
9801072
*041  $afre
*24510$aLa Nouvelle Expression. Challenge Hebdo. Le Messager
*260  $aCameroon
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aOn November 2, Mohamadou Aboui, the commander of Douala's 
anti-gang unit, and at least nine other police officers invaded the 
offices of La Nouvelle Expression, Challenge Hebdo and Le Messager in 
Douala. Severin Tchounkeu, La Nouvelle Expression's publisher, 
Challenge Hebdo's cartoonist Theo Tsapi, and the driver of Pius Njawe, 
Le Messager's publisher, were held for several hours without a warrant. 
All three were first driven to the Provincial Service for National 
Security, where clubs were used to beat them on their feet, shins, 
fingers and buttocks by Mr. Aboui and other officers. After being 
forced to bathe in mud, they were taken to the headquarters of the 
Groupe Mobile d'Intervention (GMI), where they received similar 
treatment.
*506  $bPolice officers and Douala's anti-gang unit
*518  $a2 November 1992
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5118
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*70010$aTchounkeu, Severin
*70010$aTsapi, Theo
*74000$aLa Nouvelle Expression

9801074

*24510$aGalaxie. La Nouvelle Expression. Le Messager
*260  $aCameroon
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters Sans Frontieres
*505  $aBetween July and September 1992 the three newspapers were 
suspended
*506  $bGovernment
*518  $aJuly - September 1992
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5118

9801075
*041  $afre
*24510$aLe Messager. Challenge Hebdo. Nouvelle Expression. Galaxie. 
l'Opinion. La Vision. La Detente. Dikalo
*260  $aCameroon
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992
*505  $aAbout two dozen police officers, gendarmes and Army soldiers 
surrounded the Rotoprint printing facility in Douala, in order to 
prohibit the distribution of private newspapers that had reprinted or 
commented on an interview with the former head of the Societe 
Camerounaise de Banque. The entire print run of La Nouvelle Expression 
and l'Opinion, two private newspapers, were seized. Rotoprint is one of 
two private printing facilities in Cameroon, and it publishes the 
country's leading private and opposition newspapers. Their circulation 
was blocked for about two weeks. March 24 issues of La Nouvelle 
Expression were taken off newsstands in the capital city of Yaounde. 
Reasons were not given. The May issue of the Paris-based monthly 
magazine Jeune Affrique Economie was seized during the last week of 
April by authorities at the port of Douala. The shipment was reportedly 
burned. Issues of Le Messager, Challenge Hebdo, Nouvelle Expression, 
Galaxie, l'Opinion, La Vision, La Detente and Dikalo, all Douala-based 
weekly newspapers were systematically seized throughout the month of 
May. The seizures were sparked by the newspapers' coverage of a 
controversial May interview with Robert Messi Messi, published in Jeune 
Afrique Economie. Messi is the former director of the Societe 
Camerounaise de Banque, and provided testimony and documentation 
exposing the complicity of President Paul Biya and his wife in 
embezzlement of the bank's funds.
*506  $bSecurity officers
*518  $aMay 1992
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5118
*691  $aPolitical

*692  $aSuspended

*505  $aThe 6 April 1994 edition of the newspaper "Le Messager" was 
banned by the governor of the country's coastal province, Ferdinand 
Koungou Edima, for "disturbing public order". "Le Messager" claims in a 
press release that this move is part of a campaign of censorship aimed 
at economically strangling the "Messager" group's publications. 
Previously, the newspaper's 7, 21 and 24 March editions had been 
similarly banned

9801077
*24510$aDikalo. Challenge Bi-Hebdo. Perspectives Hebdo
*260  $aCameroon
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters Sans Frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aOn 20 April 1994, Thomas Patrick Eyoum'a Noth, editor-in-chief 
of the independent weekly "Dikalo", was interrogated by the police in 
Douala, after the 18 April publication of an article entitled "Two 
Ministers `import' 17.5 million". The article said that a container 
full of banknotes had arrived in Douala several days prior transported 
by a ship from Europe, noting that this was of special interest to two 
ministers of the Republic. The police questioned Eyoum'a Noth about the 
source of his information, and released him the same day.  According to 
Cameroon's law on freedom of information of December 1990, journalists 
are not obliged to reveal their sources. This incident is the latest in 
a recent wave of censorship and harassment of the press since the 
beginning of 1994. The newspaper "Challenge Bi-Hebdo" was suspended on 
24 February for having published in two successive editions an 
interview with Ebale Angounou entitled "The Young Friend of Biya", in 
which Ebale Angounou accused the Head of State, several ministers and 
several superior officers of the Cameroon army of "bloodthirsty 
behaviour". Several editions of the weekly "Le Messager" have been 
confiscated since January, the weekly "Le Nouvel Independant" was 
suspended from 31 December 1993 until 4 March 1994, and the weekly 
"Perspectives Hebdo" has been suspended since 23 March 1994
*506  $bPolice

*24510$aLe Messager. La Nouvelle Expression. Challenge Hebdo
*260  $aCameroon
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression

*505  $aOn 5 July 1993 a dozen police officers tried to seize copies of 
"Le Messager" at the newspaper's offices. Since that date, the 
newspaper's offices have been under constant police surveillance. The 
reason for this harassment appears to be the reprinting in "Le 
Messager" of an article taken from the Parisian daily "Liberation" 
entitled "The Strange Story of President Biya's Golf Course", about the 
irregularities surrounding the construction of a golf course in the 
home town of Cameroon President Paul Biya. The 29 June 1993 issue of 
"Liberation" in which this article appeared was banned in Cameroon. On 
6 July the previous day's issue of "Le Messager" was also banned. The 
distribution of the English edition of the paper was prevented by the 
presence of police officers outside the newspaper's offices.

*24510$aLa Verdad
*260  $aEquatorial Guinea
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)
*505  $aThe monthly opposition newspaper "La verdad" has been banned by 
the government of Equatorial Guinea. "La verdad" is the only 
non-governmental publication in the country. The edict was delivered to 
the offices of the newspaper on 28 September 1993. Dated 26 September, 
it was issued by the Ministere de l'Administration Territoriale et des 
Collectivites Locales and addressed to the secretary general of the 
political party Convergence pour la Democratie Sociale (CPDS), a 
recognised opposition party which publishes "La verdad". The Ministry's 
edict constitutes neither a parliamentary resolution nor a ministerial 
ordinance. This edict appears to follow the events of 21 September when 
the political bureau of the CPDS was summoned to a meeting and Placido 
Mico, director of the paper and an official of the CPDS, was told that 
the paper would be sanctioned if its publishers did not themselves 
voluntarily cease publication

*24510$aRuh. Alef. Dewol. Mogad
*260  $aEthiopia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/International PEN Writers in Prison Committee
*505  $aAlthough there has been a burst of independent press activity 
in Ethiopia since the fall of President Mengisthu's dictatorship, with 
some 64 independent weekly and monthly publications starting up, there 
were worrying moves to clamp down on the free press. As well as the 
mass detention of journalists which took place in September/October and 
January/February, several of the independent publications were forced 
to close down. 'Ruh', 'Alef', 'Dewol' and 'Mogad' were all forced to 
close down because of financial pressures or lack of staff due to the 
arrest or constant interrogation of their journalists. 'Ruh' is accused 
of 'inciting the public' for publication of a cartoon on its cover 
which illustrates an article giving a critical report of the 
transitional government's record
*506  $bEthiopian authorities

9801086
*041  $afre
*24510$aMultipress. Sogapress
*260  $aGabon
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aGabon has recently prohibited the production and distribution 
of all independent publications. No independent newspaper or magazine 
has been published since 9 September 1993, when the Minister of 
Communications, Patrice Nziengui, ordered the public enterprises 
"Multipress", a printing company, and "Sogapress", a distributor, not 
to handle publications which do not conform to law 84/59, dating from 
1960, concerning freedom of the press. Article 7 of that law stipulates 
that the director of each publication must, 12 hours before the 
distribution of the publication, deposit two copies of the publication 
bearing his signature with the Ministry of the Interior in Libreville 
or, in other cities, with judicial authorities. The penalty for failure 
to comply with this procedure is a period of imprisonment from three 
months to a year and a fine of 10,000 to 100,000 francs (US dollar 
2,000-20,000). Some twenty newspapers or magazines have been affected 
by this order, most of them aligned with one of the opposition 
political parties. Gabon is presently beginning a period of electoral 
campaigning for upcoming elections. Since 9 September 1993, only the 
government newspaper "L'Union" has appeared
*506  $bMinister of Communications, Patrice Nziengui
$eLaw 84/59, dating from 1960, concerning freedom of the press. Article 
7 of that law stipulates that the director of each publication must, 12 
hours before the distribution of the publication, deposit two copies of 
the publication bearing his signature with the Ministry of the Interior 
in Libreville or, in other cities, with judicial authorities
*518  $a9 September 1993
$3Newspapers

*24510$aAwa (Eve)
*260  $aGambia
$c1992
*440 0$aQuarterly
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992: Fired, Editions confiscated
*505  $aJobe, editor of Awa, a woman's development quarterly, was fired 
by the Women's Bureau, an organization that publishes the journal, 
without explanation. Jobe believes she was dismissed because of a 
December 1991 column in which she said the press was glad President 
Dawda Kairaba Jarawa was going to resign. Both the leader of the 
Women's Bureau and the president's chief administrator criticized and 
questioned Jobe about the editorial, contending that Jobe had deviated 
from policy when she published without permission a political article 
in a medium that is not political. All copies of the December 1991 
issue of Awa were recalled from newsstands. Jobe was notified several 
months later that she could return to her job

9801088
*24510$aForoya
*260  $aGambia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Article 19
*505  $aRestrictions have been placed on freedom of expression and 
freedom of association since the military coup in Gambia on 22 July 
1994, during which Lt. Yahya A.J.J. Jammeh, Chairman of the Armed 
Forces and Provisional Ruling Council and Head of State, came to power. 
Ministers from the former government have been detained without charge. 
The Constitutional provision protecting the right to freedom of 
expression and association have been effectively negated. Section 23 of 
Chapter III of the Constitution of the Republic of the Gambia, which 
provides for the right to freedom of association, was revised on 29 
July 1994.In practice, this implied new restrictions that seemed to 
have been applied only to newspapers affiliated with a political party, 
such as "Foroya", published by the People's Democratic Organization for 
Independent Socialism (PDOIS). Two leaders of the PDOIS, Halifa Sallah 
and Sidia Jatta, were arrested on 19 August 1994 for continuing to 
distribute "Foroya" despite the ban
*506  $bLt. Yahya A.J.J. Jammeh, Chairman of the Armed Forces and 
Provisional Ruling Council and Head of State
$eSection 23 of Chapter III of the Constitution of the Republic of the 
Gambia

*505  $aZiabrabi, the director of publication, and "Dinard," a 
reporter, both with the newspaper l'Oeuil du Peuple, were sentenced to 
18 months in prison and fined 1.8 million CFA each for "insulting the 
head of state." The charge stems from two articles published in the 
February 11 issue entitled, "If Marie Houphouet-Boigny had been raped?" 
and "Houphouet does not spill blood, he drinks it." The articles 
citicized President Boigny for failing to punish his Army Chief, who, 
according to an official inquiry, had been responsible for a May 1991 
raid on a campus of the University of Abidjan. During the attack, 
several students were beaten and raped. The newspaper was also ordered 
suspended for three months

*505  $aArrest warrant issued for Njehu Gatabaki, Director of 'Finance'

into hiding for a few days before turning himself in around 10/11 May 
1993. Released soon after on bail and charged with sedition (article 52 
of the penal code). Reported on 11 June 1993 that Gatabaki had his 
passport confiscated. Arrested on 14 June 1993 as he was about to leave 
for Vienna  World Conference on Human Rights, although his passport had 
not been returned. Released on 19 June 1993 and charged with sedition 
in relation to the May issue of 'Finance' which was seized during the 
raid on Fotoform

*10010$aCollen, Lindsey
*24510$aThe Rape of Sita
*260  $aMauritius
$b"Ledikasyon pu Travayer" publishing company
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/International PEN WiPC
*505  $aOn 3 December 1993, "The Rape of Sita" was published by the 
"Ledikasyon pu Travayer" publishing company. Five days later Prime 
Minister Sir Aneerood Jugnauth made a statement in Parliament saying 
that "a glance at the back page of the book [which gives a 6-paragraph 
summary of its contents] suffices to indicate that this publication may 
constitute an outrage against public and religious morality". He 
ordered that the book be banned under the Criminal Code, and referred 
in his statement to a similar decision to ban Salman Rushdie's "Satanic 
Verses" in February 1989.  As a result, the author and publisher 
voluntarily withdrew the book from circulation, saying that this would 
provide time for a debate, enough books having already been sold to 
allow for this. On 30 December 1993 the Minister for Arts, Culture, 
Leisure and Reform Institutions confirmed the banning order and added 
that it may be lifted should the title of the book be changed. The 
controversy around the book led to anonymous threats against the author
*506  $bPrime Minister Sir Aneerood Jugnauth
$eThe Mauritian Criminal Code Sub-section 206(1)a(ii) states that any 
person who sells or distributes material which commits an "outrage" 
against any religion can be imprisoned for up to one year
*518  $aDecember 1993
$3Book
*651  $a5442
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
*74000$aThe Rape of Sita

*505  $aConcord Press, publisher of several publications, including 
African Concord magazine, was closed by security agents without 
explanation. Six days later the Minister of Information announced that 
the company had been shut down "to preserve national security." The 
closure probably was in reaction to the April 13 issue of African 
Concord magazine, which carried an article entitled, "Has Babangida 
Given Up?" The article examined corruption, poor leadership, a 
collapsing educational system and the government's economic polices. 
Concord was allowed to reopen two weeks later

*505  $aOn 2 January 1994 thousands of copies of the weekly magazine 
"Tell" were seized. Reports indicate that the cover story of the seized 
issue was titled "The Return of Tyranny: Abacha bares his teeth", which 
reported on the decrees issued two weeks ago which dismissed several 
matters before the courts so as to favour the new military regime. It 
is believed that this article prompted the seizure of around 50,000 
copies of the magazine in Lagos. In May 1993, 70,000 copies of the 
magazine had been seized by the previous government

9801102
*041  $aeng
*24510$aThe Guardian. Concord. Punch
*260  $aNigeria
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters Sans Frontieres (RSF, Paris)
*505  $aA 6 September 1994 government decree put a six month ban on 
three independent newspaper groups, Guardian, Punch and Concord, which 
have seen their share of occupations and closures, now a common 
occurrence in Nigeria. Decrees issued on 6 September are an attempt to 
give retroactive legal justification for press freedom violations which 
have occurred over the past few months. There have been several attacks 
on the three newspaper groups in previous months. In June, Concord and 
Punch were ordered closed. The night of 14 to 15 August, armed police 
officers closed down the Guardian. Since 11 June 1994, security forces 
have been occupying the offices of the Concord group and its head, 
Moshood Abiola, an opponent of the government and presumed winner of 
last year's annulled presidential election, was arrested and remains in 
jail. A 19 August High Court decision had, to no avail, ordered the 
government to evacuate the offices and pay damages to Concord for 
income lost due to the closure. The 11 June closing order affecting the 
offices of Punch was lifted in July by the High Court. 10 December 1994 
marked the end of the six month bans imposed on the Punch and Concord 
newspaper groups. However, on 12 December, the independent newspaper 
groups Punch, Concord and Guardian were newly banned by government 
decree for a duration of six months. Without making the decision 
public, Minister of Justice and Attorney General Michael Agbamuche 
informed the groups that any attempts to go against the decree would be 
met with severe repression. Punch, who on 12 December published the 
first edition in six months of its weekly, "Punch," once again ceased 
publication
*506  $bMinister of Justice and Attorney General Michael Agbamuche
*518  $a6 September, 12 December 1994

*505  $aOn 2 June 1994 the Paris-based weekly "Jeune Afrique" was

in damages and interest. The Senegalese Minister of Justice, Mr. 
Jacques Baudin, confirmed 3 August 1994 that the government lifted a 
one-year ban against the Paris-based weekly magazine "Jeune Afrique" 
and dropped charges against its editor-in-chief, Mr. Ben Yahmed.

*505  $aOn 24 February 1994, security officials raided the newspaper's 
Khartoum offices and arrested Mutasim Mahmoud, ordering all staff to

arrest of Mutasim Mahmoud is not known although it is likely to be 
connected to articles published by the newspaper criticizing the government. 
The authorities apparently have claimed he was engaged in anti-state 
activities. Independent newspapers were banned in Sudan following the 
seizure of power by the military government in June 1989. At the 
beginning of 1994 there was a relaxation in the media laws, allowing 
selected newspapers to start operating. "Al-Sudani al-Doulia", which 
was previously based in Beirut, was granted a license to operate in 
Khartoum in January 1994. The newspaper has recently published articles 
criticizing government policies and performance

a weekly news magazine, Sayidati, a weekly women's magazine, and 
Al-Muslimoun, a weekly newspaper. The letter accused these publications 
of publishing "fabricated lies and pure propaganda."

*505  $aOn 21 January 1994 the government closed down the weekly

religious leader. At the time, a government spokesperson said Baraza 
had been closed "temporarily" because editor Hassan Yahya was not 
suitably qualified; the paper had published "malicious news"; and 
because the government had not been informed that Baraza had moved to a 
different printing firm. All are considered offenses under Tanzania's 
Newspaper Act of 1976

*505  $aThe government of Zaire has closed the daily newspaper "Umoja" 
and the weekly "La Renaissance" for publishing articles critical of the 
introduction of a new national currency, the "nouveau zaire". The two 
newspapers, belonging to the same publishing company, published on 25 
October 1992 a statement by the Union Sacree de l'Opposition Radicale 
(USOR, an opposition political party) calling on people to boycott the 
currency. On 27 October the government suspended both publications for 
three months. According to reports, on 22 October 1992, the day after 
the new currency was launched, the government of Faustin Birindwa 
warned the media that any critical commentary on the new currency would 
result in closure within 24 hours of the report and a prison term for 
the newspaper's editor

9801123
*041  $aspa
*10010$aPalamara, Humberto
*24510$aEtica y Servicios de Inteligencia
*260  $aChile
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/International PEN WiPC
*505  $aCaptain Humberto Palamara, a former Navy intelligence officer 
in Chile who wrote a book about military ethics, was informed on 27 
October 1994 that the Naval Prosecutor had sentenced him to 541 days in 
prison for non-compliance with military duties (under article 299 of 
the Military Code of Justice), to three years in prison for 
disobedience (article 337 of the Military Code of Justice) and 541 days 
in prison for disobedience (article 336 of the Military Code of 
Justice). He will be expected to serve the sentences consecutively. The 
first sentence is said to be for the contents of his book; the 
three-year sentence is for refusing to hand over his book and the third 
sentence is for a statement he made to a local newspaper denouncing his 
treatment following the seizure of his book, "Etica y Servicios de 
Inteligencia" ("Ethics and Military Intelligence"), after he had 
received an order telling him not to criticise the Navy. Despite 
attempts to portray this case as one of military insubordination, it is 
clear that censorship of the book is the real issue
*506  $bThe Naval Prosecutor
*518  $aMarch 1993

9801126
*041  $aspa
*24510$aCronica. Critica
$b[All media]
*260  $aGuatemala
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Inter Press Service International News Agency
*505  $aGuatemalan President Jorge Serrano Elias has used the sweeping 
powers he seized last week to intimidate and silence the media, one of 
the only institutions to gain a degree of strength under Guatemala's 
young democracy. Since suspending constitutional rule last week, Elias 
has sent in police to surround press buildings, seize newspapers, cut 
national television, block incoming television from abroad and fill the 
radio waves with official programming. And, in a return to 
psychological tactics used when the army was in power, reporters have 
received death threats. The national press has now either shut down or 
is working under heavy censorship with gaps in the editorial pages, 
while one independent television station is closed and another is 
censored. Television screens go blank and crackle with static whenever 
news programs from abroad, including CNN, Univision and Mexico's ECO, 
turn to events in Guatemala. Serrano announced he was dissolving 
Congress and suspending the constitution last Tuesday. The official 
network blared marimba music through the radio waves for hours 
afterwards, until Serrano could move his censors into place in their 
newsrooms. On Friday, soldiers wandered up the streets snatching copies 
of Cronica, and another news weekly called Critica, from 
newsstands.Cronica, a fierce but measured critic of Serrano, on Friday 
conned censors into believing they were still editing when in fact they 
were printing, and distributed 2,500 copies with the protection of 
diplomats and the international press
*506  $bPresident Jorge Serrano Elias
*518  $a31 May 1993
$3All media
*651  $a6236
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*74000$aCronica
*74000$aCritica
^

*260  $aGuatemala
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression

*505  $aThe publications Prensa Libre and Siglo XXI, refused to allow 
censors to enter their respective premises. Since Wednesday morning 
units of National and Treasury police have surrounded the offices of 
both newspapers. The government has threatened to take drastic measures 
if the publications refused to accept official censorship. Without 
explanation, it is known that there are official orders at the 
international airport to prevent the departure of various journalists, 
including a number of directors of newspapers, the editor of a magazine 
and others. On Tuesday night, the television channels 11 and 13 
broadcasted an interview with Human Rights Procurator Ramiro de Leon 
Carpio in which he called President Serrano a "dictator". The 
Guatemalan Ombudsman managed to escape the police surrounding his home 
and, assisted by the diplomatic corps in the country, remains active. 
The security forces immediately blocked the television signals of the 
two stations

publication. Television channels 11 and 13 are not broadcasting their 
normal newscasts. Channel Seven, through agents of the Secretary of 
Public Relations for the government, is broadcasting news favourable to 
the government. Radio newscasts have been suspended. The government now 
operates an uninterrupted national radio station. The government has 
also intensified its control of the media by prohibiting various 
international news agencies from reporting on Guatemala outside the 
country. Among those affected are the Mexican news agency Notimex and 
the Central American News Agency (ACAN-EFE)

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression

*505  $aOn 4 August 1993 at 10:00 a.m. the printing plant of the

the Guatemalan armed forces. The soldiers entered by the rear door and 
asked what the nature of the magazine is. On that same day, earlier in 
the morning, the magazine's delivery truck had been stopped by a 
national police car, who asked to see the driver's licence and 
identification. They then searched the van and asked what was in the 
bundles found inside. When informed that the bundles contained issues 
of the magazine "Tinamit", the officers responded that they could be 
considered subversive material

*24510$aTinamit
*260  $aGuatemala
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression

*505  $aOn January 1, a group of armed individuals violently took over 
the magazine's printing house, spraying the equipment with gasoline and 
setting it afire. The men fled after the attack. The magazine, which 
was launched in February 1992, specializes in political and social 
analysis, and has a large readership among Guatemala's grassroots 
movement. In October 1992, members of staff of "Tinamit" magazine 
reported to the Human Rights Office of the Archbishop of Guatemala that 
they had received anonymous death threats, both written and by 
telephone. On October 4, Hugo Arce, columnist with "Tinamit" magazine, 
received threatening phone calls that he believed were in connection 
with articles he had written on the assassination of anthropologist 
Myrna Mack. On October 5, a bomb attack on the offices of "Tinamit" 
resulted in heavy property damage

*24510$aSiglo XXI
*260  $aGuatemala
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/CEPEX - Costa Rica
*505  $aOn January 7, the day after the Human Rights Ombudsman made a 
statement on the December 3 beating of a journalist and 
environmentalists by the military, a group of armed men seized a 
delivery truck carrying part of the edition of "Siglo XXI" newspaper 
which contained a front page story on the Ombudsman's statement, and 
reportedly set fire to the newspapers. Reportedly, on December 3, Omar 
Cano Herrera, a journalists with "Siglo XXI", and his environmentalist 
companions, were repeatedly beaten for up to three hours by a group of 
armed individuals dressed as civilians while they were investigating 
the illegal cutting of forests in the El Peten province of northern 
Guatemala. Cano's journalistic materials were destroyed, and he was hit 
several times in the back with one of his cameras. Cano and his 
companions, specialists from the National Council of Protected Areas 
(CONAP), were then handed over to the region's military base by the 
attackers. The attackers were not apprehended. Violent attacks against 
the press in Guatemala started in mid-December after President Jorge 
Serrano Elias made a series of inflammatory statements against the press
*506  $bArmed individuals
*518  $a7 January 1993

9801132
*041  $aspa
*24510$aCronica
*260  $aGuatemala
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Journalists' Centre for Freedom of Expression (CEPEX- San

*505  $aOn 14 August 1994 Francisco Perez de Anton, the editor of the 
weekly magazine "Cronica," denounced the religious sect Opus Dei for 
trying to hurt his magazine financially in order to prevent it from 
publishing news about the International Conference on Population and 
Development to take place in Cairo in September. "Cronica," the weekly 
with the highest circulation in Guatemala, has for the past month been 
reporting on reproductive health, women's and children's rights, as 
well as opposition by the Catholic Church to Guatemalans having 
information on these subjects. The reaction of the Catholic Church has 
not been to wait. Besides decrying that subjects to be discussed at the 
Conference include abortion and homosexuality, Opus Dei, a very 
influential sector of the Catholic hierarchy, has managed to pressure 
businesses into discontinuing their advertisements in "Cronica."
*506  $bOpus Dei (Catholic church)
*518  $a22 August 1994
$3Newspaper
*651  $a6236
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*74000$aCronica
^

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression

*505  $aMore than nine thousand copies of the magazine "Cronica" which 
had been seized by the police on 28 May 1993 were discovered burned on 
26 July on the outskirts of Guatemala City. The director and deputy 
director of the magazine, Gustavo Berganza and Haroldo Shetemul, 
denounced the act. Who burned the magazine is unknown, but magazine 
personnel suspect members of the National Police. The 28 May issue of 
"Cronica" was dedicated to an analysis and condemnation of the 
"self-coup" of ex-president Jorge Serrano Elias. It was confiscated on 
its release by order of the regime. A small number of issues of this 
edition circulated in a clandestine fashion but the majority were 
confiscated by the police

$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Canadian Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aHaiti's government took peacefully control of state media, but 
other incidents of gunfire and violence shook the capital. Accompanied 
by heavily armed police and soldiers wearing bulletproof vests, Prime 
Minister Robert Malval entered the government television and radio 
stations and installed two new directors, officials said. For three 
weeks armed police auxiliaries, or attaches, had blocked Malval's new 
government from taking control of the state media, which have been 
transmitting an unrelenting stream of messages against toppled 
President Jean-Bertrand Aristide

9801142
*041  $aeng
*24510$a[All Media]
*260  $aUnited States
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992
*505  $aA top official of the Census Bureau ordered that all "major 
media" be referred to the Public Information Office for even the 
simplest of queries, "such as the number of housing units in the U.S. 
in 1990." It specifically excluded less-than-major media, citing this 
example: "On the other hand, if a reporter from the Sacramento Bee asks 
for numbers for such a publication, you may give it to him/her." The 
memo identified "major media" as large newspapers, magazines and TV 
networks. The directive came soon after a census employee had 
embarassed the Bush administration by releasing estimates on the number 
of casualties inflicted in Iraq by allied military forces during the 
Persian Gulf War.

9801143
*041  $aeng
*24510$aSan Francisco Bay Times
*260  $aUnited States
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992
*505  $aFour thousand copies of the May 7 edition of San Francisco Bay 
Times disappeared from news racks. San Francisco Police Chief Richard 
Hongisto was fired May 15 on the grounds that he had told police 
officers to confiscate the newspapers. The gay biweekly featured a 
cover story May 7 that severely criticized Hongisto's crackdown on 
crime in San Francisco after riots broke out there in response to the 
Rodney King verdict in Los Angeles. The cover illustration depicted 
Hongisto's head on the body of a female police officer who was holding 
a police baton in a sexually suggestive manner. The headline read, 
"Dick's Cool New Tool: Martial Law."

*24510$aAzadlig
*260  $aAzerbaidjan

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aOn 18 April 1994 police raided the offices of the newspaper 
"Azadlig" and detained five of its journalists. They are: Ganimat 
Zabidov, Hikmet Zeynalov, Rafig Mammadali, Gorkhmaz Ibrahimov and Kanan 
Salimov. All are members of the newspaper's editorial staff. They were 
arrested and taken to military police headquarters in Baku, where they 
were held for several hours. The newspaper was unable to publish the 
following day, 19 April, as a result of the police action. The police, 
who were acting without arrest or search warrants, were believed to be 
searching for weapons in the newspaper's offices. BACKGROUND "Azadlig" 
is the organ of the Azerbaidjani Popular Front. In September 1993 the 
police seized and destroyed an entire edition of the newspaper

9801157
*041  $aben
*10010$aNasrin, Taslima
*24510$aLaijla (and others)
*260  $aBangladesh
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/PEN 
International
*505  $a24 September 1994 the Bangladeshi writer and journalist, 
Taslima Nasreen, was reportedly condemned to death by a militant Muslim 
group. The reason behind the threat to Nasreen's life are said to be 
her numerous novels which criticised Muslim fundamentalism and male 
chauvinism. The book which causes particular outcry in the militant 
Muslim community is "Laija" (The Shame) which had been published to 
critical acclaim in February that year. Released during Bangladesh's 
biggest bookfair, "Laija" became a best selling novel within a week of 
its publication. It is said to have sold over 50,000 copies in six 
months. It was banned by the Bangladeshi government in July on grounds 
that it had "created misunderstanding among communities". The banning 
order was publicly condemned by leading Bangladeshi intellectuals, 
writers and human rights activisits. The Bangladesh authorities did 
provide police protection to Nasrin, but refused pleas from the 
international and national communities to lift the ban on her book and 
to publicly condemn all calls for attacks against her. Police 
protection was reportedly withdrawn a few days before the arrest 
warrant was issued on 4 June. Nasreen is also known for her strong 
feminist views and has written a number of books and articles on 
women's rights. These have led to further calls for punishment on 
charges of blasphemy.
*506  $bNon-Government fundamentalists (Towhidi Jagrata Janata) and the 
government
$eArticle 295A of the Bangladeshi Penal Code on charges of "insulting 
religion and religious sentiments"
*518  $a30 September 1994

*651  $a7413

*692  $aCensored

9801158
*041  $acam
*24510$aSokal
*260  $aCambodia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)
*505  $aOn 16 May 1994 Ministry of the Interior forces surrounded the 
publishing house of "Sokal Newspaper". 10,000 copies were seized by 
police because the newspaper that day allegedly criticised King Norodom 
Sihanouk, in violation of the new Cambodian constitution, whose Article 
7 prohibits all criticism of the King. "Sokal" published articles and 
drawings suggesting that the King was responsible for more than a 
million deaths during the four year rule of the Khmer Rouge, until 
1978. Publishing equipment were seized and the newspaper was closed 
down. A cabinet minister, Troeung Maly, indicated that on three 
occasions the newspaper had offended the King. No court ruling has been 
made against the newspaper, however.
*506  $bMinistry of the Interior forces
$eArticle 7, which prohibits all criticism of the King
