9801159
*041  $achi
*24510$aEconomics Weekly
*260  $aChina
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aJournalist Gao Yu, former deputy editor-in-chief of the 
newspaper, was formally arrested and charged with "leaking state 
secrets abroad" on October 13, Chinese officials told her family. China 
holds more journalists in its prisons than any other country in the 
world. Censorship of news which could reflect badly on the government 
and of political opinions contrary to those of the ruling Chinese 
Communist Party remains strict, despite recent relaxation of controls 
over "soft" news which have given Chinese news media a livelier 
appearance in the past year. "Economics Weekly", the respected 
newspaper owned by imprisoned dissidents Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming 
for which Gao Yu worked, was closed down by the authorities in June 
1989. On 11 November 1994, a Chinese official informed the family of 
dissident journalist Gao u that she had been sentenced to six years in 
prison for "leaking state secrets," following a closed trial in which 
she had no legal representation.
*506  $bChinese authorities
*518  $a19 October 1993

*651  $a7117

*505  $aSix journalists are among the many opposition figures arrested 
by Georgian authorities throughout October 1993. Irakli Gotsiridze, 
Editor-in-Chief of the newspaper "Iberia Spektra", which has been 
banned, was arrested on 3 October and was reportedly beaten during his 
interrogation. He has been accused of treason. Levan (or Revaz) 
Uruschadze, a journalist with "Iberia Spektra" and spokesperson for the 
Georgian Helsinki Union, was arrested on 3 October. Tinatin 
Mgwdlinaschvili, writer and journalist, was arrested 3 October. Nino 
Usnadze, member of the editorial committee of the banned newspaper 
"Sakartvelos Samreklo" was arrested 3 October. Mamana Arabidze, member 
of the editorial committee of the banned newspaper "Sakartvelos 
Samreklo". Mukhran Madzhavariani, poet and journalist, member of the 
Union of Independent Writers, arrested 19 October. No information is 
available as to the exact reasons for these journalists' arrests nor 
the whereabouts of their detention. It would appear that their arrests 
were motivated solely by their open criticism of government actions

*505  $aA government agency has censured a leading news magazine for

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression

*505  $aCopies of the Tamil weekly Nakkheeran were seized and burned in 
towns throughout Tamil Nadu, and news hawkers were assaulted. A 
political tabloid, Nakkheeran had been running a column titled "Here is 
another Hitler" written by a Congress (I) leader, K. Subbu, which 
criticized Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Jayalalitha Jayaram. The editor 
and publisher, Mr. R. Rajagopal, had received anonymous threatening 
phone calls and letters, and in late 1991, water and electricity 
supplies to the paper's office were disconnected and restored only 
following the intervention of the Madras High Court.

9801176
*041  $ahin
*24510$aIndian Express
*260  $aIndia
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992
*505  $aOn the nights of February 15 and 16, censors from the Home 
Department of the Chandigarh Administration of Punjab demanded the 
removal of news items about calls to boycott the election. The order by 
the executive magistrate of Chandigarh, later published in the paper, 
said "objectionable material" was removed that was "likely to incite 
disaffection towards the government." Writing to the Punjab governor, 
the paper's editor said, "Both the stories were political statements by 
recognized political parties, and were by way of reaction to the Home 
Minister's earlier statements published by the newspapers."
*506  $bCensors from the Home Department of the Chandigarh

9801182
*041  $aind
*10010$aToer, Pramoedya Ananta
*24510$aThis Earth of Mankind
*260  $aIndonesia
$c1981
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/International PEN Writer's in Prison Committee 1993 Report
*505  $aNovelist, author of 'This Earth of Mankind', 'Child of all 
Nations', 'Footsteps' and 'Glass House', published by Penguin Books and 
all written when he was a political prisoner on Indonesia's Buru 
Island. He has also translated novels by Steinbeck, Tolstoy and Gorki 
into Indonesian, among others. Books banned in 1981 although they had 
become best-sellers and it is estimated that half a million photocopies 
of the last novel in the 'This Earth of Mankind' tetralogy are in 
illegal circulation in Indonesia. Toer is now under town arrest and 
under police surveillance. Reportedly not in very good health. People 
caught in possession of his books have received prison sentences for 
spreading Marxist ideas. Imprisoned from 1965 to 1979.
*506  $bIndonesian authorities
*518  $a1981
$3Book
*651  $a7526
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*692  $aBanned
*74000$aThis Earth of Mankind

*041  $aind
*10010$aToer, Pramoedya Ananta
*24510$aGlass House
*260  $aIndonesia
$c1988
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/International PEN Writer's in Prison Committee 1993 Report
*505  $aNovelist, author of 'This Earth of Mankind', 'Child of all 
Nations', 'Footsteps' and 'Glass House', published by Penguin Books and 
all written when he was a political prisoner on Indonesia's Buru 
Island. He has also translated novels by Steinbeck, Tolstoy and Gorki 
into Indonesian, among others. Books banned in 1981 although they had 
become best-sellers and it is estimated that half a million photocopies 
of the last novel in the 'This Earth of Mankind' tetralogy are in 
illegal circulation in Indonesia. Toer is now under town arrest and 
under police surveillance. Reportedly not in very good health. People 
caught in possession of his books have received prison sentences for 
spreading Marxist ideas. Imprisoned from 1965 to 1979. In 1988, Toer's 
publisher, PT Hasta Mitra, tried to publish the 'Glass House' but it 
was banned soon after on June 8 1988 because as the Minister for 
Politics and Security put it, 'The book clearly reveals Karl Marx's 
labour theory as well as continuing Leninist themes. The book also 
contains clauses supporting the concept of social classes which is 
against Pancasila'
*506  $bIndonesian authorities
*518  $a8 June 1988
$3Book
*651  $a7526
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*692  $aBanned
*74000$aGlass House

9801188
*041  $aind
*24510$aTempo. Editor. Detik
*260  $aIndonesia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Amnesty International (AI)
*505  $aThe banning of Indonesia's three leading news magazines -- 
"Tempo", "Editor", and "Detik" -- in late June has contributed to a 
deepening climate of fear among journalists and editors, resulting in 
the widespread practice of self-censorship. Limitations on the freedom 
of the press have also further restricted the channels available to 
human rights activists and other peaceful critics of the government to 
air their views. The climate of fear has been exacerbated by the 
heavy-handed response to peaceful protest against the bans
*506  $bGovernment
*518  $aJune 1994
$3Newspapers
*651  $a7526
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*692  $aBanned
*74000$aTempo
*74000$aEditor
*74000$aDetik

9801189
*041  $aind
*24510$aMonitor
*260  $aIndonesia
$c1991
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/International PEN Writer's in Prison Committee 1993 Report
*505  $aArswendo Atmowiloto: 42-year-old short story writer and editor 
of the banned tabloid newspaper, Monitor, detained for blasphemy and 
'spreading hatred' after publishing a readers' popularity poll in 
October in which he ranked one place above the Prophet Muhammad. The 
Chief Justice has said that his poll created social unrest - there were 
demonstrations in several cities condemning the magazine and in Jakarta 
the magazine's offices were attacked. Trial began on 24 January 1991. 
Sentenced to five years in prison on 8 April 1991. Magazine and books 
banned and has been driven out of Indonesian Journalists' Association. 
Sentence reported to have been reduced by six months on appeal in July 
1991. Transferred to Cipinang Prison in February 1992.
*506  $bChief Justice
*518  $a24 January 1991
$3Newspaper
*651  $a7526
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*692  $aBanned
*74000$aMonitor
^
9801190
*041  $aind
*10010$aLiotohe, Wimanjaya
*24510$aPrima Dosa (Prime Sin)
*260  $aIndonesia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/International PEN Writers in Prison Committee
*505  $aDissident writer, Liotohe, Wimanjaya, is reported to have been 
taken for police interrogation on 13 April 1994 for his book, "Prima 
Dosa" (Prime Sin), which was banned in January 1994. The book is 
accused of "attacking and spreading lies" about President Suharto. He 
was still being interrogated as of 15 April. If convicted for his book, 
he faces a maximum seven year and four months prison term. As of last 
reports, he had not yet been charged, although he had faced similar 
interrogation in January at the time his book was banned. The book, 
which makes allegations that President Suharto was involved in the 1965 
coup which overthrew his predecessor, Sukarno, was withdrawn from 
circulation in January after protests from the President
*506  $bPresident Suharto
*518  $a13 April 1994

*651  $a7526

*10010$aMoe, Tin
*24510$aPalm Leaf Manuscript
*260  $aMyanmar (Burma)
$c1991
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/International PEN Writer's in Prison Committee 1993 Report
*505  $aMoe, Tin: Well-known poet and essayist whose work has been. 
Also editor of well-known and banned literary magazine, 'Palm Leaf 
Manuscript' which was considered left-wing. Arrested in December 1991, 
possibly in connection with student demonstrations in Rangoon which 
called, among other things, for the release of Aung San Suu Kyi. Was 
literary consultant to Aung San Suu Kyi and active in the NLD. His 
magazine was closed down by the gov't. one month after he became 
editor. Sentenced in civil court to four years in prison at beginning 
of July 1992

9801199
*041  $aeng
*24510$aThe Economist
*260  $aSingapore
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reuter
*505  $aSingapore imposed a limit on sales of the Economist March 3 
1993, and warned it will cut the magazine's circulation unless it 
publishes a government statement. A government order said the 
Economist's circulation will be limited to the present level of 7,500 
as of today because the British magazine refused to publish a 
government response to a letter by an opposition politician. "The 
government will reduce this circulation progressively, beginning with 
the issue of 14-20 August 1993, unless the Economist publishes the 
reply,'" the order said. Singapore has previously restricted the 
circulation of Time magazine, the Asian Wall Street Journal, and the 
regional magazines Asiaweek and the Far Eastern Economic Review
*506  $bGovernment
*518  $a3 March 1993
$3Magazine
*651  $a7546
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*74000$aThe Economist

*74000$aFar Eastern Economic Review

9801200
*041  $akor
*10010$aYon-in, Kim
$epublisher
*24510$aThe Theory of the Student Movement. The Practice of Socialism. 
The Smelters
*260  $aSouth Korea
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/International PEN Writers in Prison Committee (International 
PEN WiPC)
*505  $aThirteen writers, publishers and editors are known to be held 
under South Korea's National Security Law (NSL), arrested as long ago 
as 1985 and as recently as March 1994. They are serving sentences of up 
to life imprisonment. The most recent arrests, which took place in 
March 1994, are of publishers accused of having published pro-North 
Korean material. They are: KIM Yon-in, the owner of Heem Publishing 
Company, who was arrested on 23 March 1994. He was accused of 
publishing and disseminating material benefitting North Korea. Among 
the books reported to have been confiscated from publishing house on 
his arrest was "The Theory of the Student Movement". LEE Song-woo and 
KIM Byong-hak, the owner and managing director respectively of Ilbit 
publishing company, who were arrested on 18 March 1994. Books and 
computer diskettes alleged to be pro-North Korea were confiscated 
although many were legally published and are sold in bookshops. The 
books confiscated include "The Practice of Socialism", poetry by Jung 
In-hwa and prison writings by former political prisoners. On 19 April 
1994, Park Chi-kwan, chief editor of the Il-t'eo Publishing Company, 
was reportedly taken for questioning by officers from the Seoul 
Metropolitan Police. Shortly after his arrest, officers are said to 
have gone to his offices and seized around 200 copies of the book, "The 
Smelters", a North Korean novel on the life of iron-workers in the 
North, and computer discs.
*506  $bGovernment
*506  $eNational Security Law
*518  $a1985 - 1994
$3Books
*651  $a7144
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*692  $aSeized
*70010$aSong-woo, Lee
$epublisher
*70010$aByong-hak, Kim
$epublisher
*70010$aIn-hwa, Jung
$eauthor
*70010$aChi-kwan, Park
$epublisher

*74000$aThe Practice of Socialism
*74000$aThe Smelters

9801202
*041  $aeng
*24510$aSolomon Islands Broadcasting Corporation (SIBC)
*260  $aSolomon Islands
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/IFEX/ Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aAn order was imposed on the Solomon Islands Broadcasting 
Corporation (SIBC) censoring any reporting of the crisis in 
Bougainville. There is currently a civil war between secessionist 
forces in Bougainville and the central government of Papua New Guinea. 
According to the Solomon Star, on April 21, 1993, the Prime Minister 
restricted the broadcasting of news about Bougainville on the grounds 
that it was "likely to contravene the principles of the Public Security 
and Official Secrets Acts." More than a year ago, another executive 
decision was made to subject all news about Bougainville to prior 
approval and to fire Johnson Honimae, the head of SIBC's Current 
Affairs Division.
*506  $bGovernment
*518  $a5 May 1993
$3All media
*651  $a9027
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*74000$aSolomon Islands Broadcasting Corporation (SIBC)
^
9801203
*041  $ataj
*24510$aCheraq Rouze
*260  $aTajikistan
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters Sans Frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aSince 1992, the government of Tadzhikistan has conducted a 
systematic crackdown on Tadzhik independent media. During this period, 
CPJ has documented the killing of 27 journalists by groups closely 
linked to the current government. In addition, four television 
journalists have been languishing in a Dushanbe prison since their 
arrest on March 23, 1993 and many journalists have been forced into 
exile. The pro-Islamic daily, "Cheraq Rouze" (Light of Day) was banned. 
The journalists were believed to be associated with the Rasthokhez 
(Revival) Democratic Movement, one of the main members of the 
'Islamo-Democratic' opposition coalition
*506  $bGovernment
*518  $a1992
$3Newspaper
*651  $a7241
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored

*24510$aAl Arab International

$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aIn January 1993 the Arabic-language daily Al Arab 
International, which is published in London, celebrated its first 
anniversary of being banned on French soil. The ban was imposed because 
it was feared the pro-lraqi newspaper might 'disturb public order' 
during the Gulf War. The Interior Ministry said Al Arab International 
defended views that were 'contrary to those of France'.

*505  $aOn 16 October defence minister Pierre Joxe lifted bans on three 
publications in force since 1980 that prevented them being distributed 
on military premises, in accordance with the spirit of openness and 
dialogue decided on at the start of this year'. Soldiers are now free 
to read the satirical weekly Charlie-Hebdo, Le Journal des Objecteurs, 
and Rouge, published by the extreme-left Revolutionary Communist 
League, in the comfort of their barracks

9801213
*041  $acrp
*24510$aSlobodna Dalmacija
*260  $aCroatia
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aThe Croatian government took over the daily Slobodna Dalmacija, 
which has been an important independent voice in Croatia. According to 
reports, in October 1992, the government, claiming that Slobodna 
Dalmacija had not followed the appropriate procedures in becoming a 
private enterprise, appointed a new board of directors. A majority of 
the shares were reportedly sold to state interests, rather than to the 
newspaper's employees, as required by law. This month, a new editorial 
board was installed at the newspaper that is apparently more in line 
with the government's point of view
*506  $bGovernment
*518  $a29 March 1993
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8055
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored

9801214
*041  $afre
*24510$aEl Moutaouasset
*260  $aFrance
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters Sans Frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aOn 3 December 1993 Abdessalem Bouchadekh, director of the 
bi-monthly magazine "El Moutaouasset", published in Arabic in Paris, 
received a letter from the Director of the Public Freedoms and Judicial 
Affairs Department of the Interior Ministry informing him that "because 
of its extremely violent anti-Western and anti-French tone and the 
slander against Jews which it contains" the magazine "may disturb 
public order" and thus be subject to an order "banning its circulation, 
distribution and sale in France, in light of Article 14 of the law 
dated 29 July 1881 on freedom of the press". The ministry has since 
refused further comment on these accusations. Abdessalem Bouchadekh is 
a Tunisian refugee in France since 1978. He has also received a notice 
from the police department of Noisy le Grand, dated 5 January 1994, 
indicating that his residency permit will be withdrawn tomorrow, 14 
January 1994. As a refugee, Abdessalem Bouchadekh holds a residency 
permit which expires 13 January 1996. A request to renew his 
authorisation to travel outside the country was already refused on 13 
December 1993
*506  $bDirector of the Public Freedoms and Judicial Affairs Department 
of the Interior Ministry
*518  $a3 December 1993
$3Bi-monthly magazine
*651  $a8023
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*74000$aEl Moutaouasset
^
9801215
*041  $aara
*24510$aAl Arab. Al Dustur. Kol Al Arab
*260  $aFrance
$c1991
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Reporters Sans Frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aOn 26 January 1991, a few days after the beginning of the Gulf 
War, the French government banned the daily newspaper "Al Arab", the 
monthly "Al Dustur" (both published in London) and the daily "Kol Al 
Arab", published in Paris. The reason given the newspapers "may disturb 
public order" and thus be subject to an order "banning its circulation, 
distribution and sale in France, in light of Article 14 of the law 
dated 29 July 1881 on freedom of the press". Four days prior to these 
bannings Shamir Khairi Tawfiq, editor-in-chief of "Kol Al Arab", was 
deported from the country by virtue of an "absolute emergency procedure"
*506  $bGovernment
*506  $eArticle 14 of the law dated 29 July 1881 on freedom of the press

*505  $aRomanian President Ion Iliescu has revoked the accreditation of

9801220
*041  $ascc
*24510$aBorba
*260  $aSerbia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/ARTICLE 19
*505  $aThe Serbian government has moved to close "Borba", a Serbian 
newspaper, on the grounds that "Borba's" company registration, which 
was gazetted in July 1991, was technically flawed and is therefore 
invalid. On 8 November 1994, the Commercial Court in Belgrade delivered 
its verdict against the Borba Shareholding Company in a judgement that 
argued that the establishment of the shareholding company had never 
been valid because the 1991 contract was signed by an "unauthorized 
person", on behalf of the then Federal Secretariat for Information. 
"Borba" is currently appealing this decision. The editors of the paper 
believe that the right to publish is being withdrawn for political 
reasons. "Borba"'s suspicions of political harassment are aggravated by 
the sudden and recent appearance of government objections to the status 
of the paper.
*506  $bGovernment
*518  $a8 November 1994
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8053
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*74000$aBorba
^

*500  $aSource: Library of Congress, USA
*505  $aIncludes bibliographical references and index.
*505  $aSummary: Looks at the accountability - or increasingly the lack of accountability - of Australia's state and federal governments. Its focus is on the government-directed public-sector reforms of the last two decades that have made governments less accountable for service delivery, and the repercussions these reforms have had.
